undulose extinction and straight boundaries that form dihedral contact at 120º. The GT rock unit 

shows variable amounts of melanocratic to mesocratic enclaves. Extensive bodies free of mafic 

enclaves also occur. The lack of enclaves may be explained by one or more of the following reasons: i) 

exposures of plutons cut in different erosional levels (like in eroded batholiths composed of incestuous 

plutons; Pitcher 1997); ii) upper crustal level, allochthonous plutons emplaced far from magma mixing 

zones; iii) plutons or part of them composed of more evolved melts formed from fractional 

crystallization; iv) plutons or part of them composed by more differentiated melts formed by partial 

melting of other granitic plutons of the arc itself and/or from basement sources of adequate 

composition. 

 

GEOCHEMISTRY OF THE G1 SUPERSUITE 

 The analyzed samples include 8 tonalites/enderbites (ETG, GT and Opx-bearing groups), 11 

granodiorites (ETG and GT groups), 4 monzogranites (GT group), 1 gabbro (Opx-bearing group), and 

1 diorite (Opx-bearing group) (Table 3.2).   

The analyzed rocks forming the G1 Supersuite in the study area vary from diorite to alkali-

granite, with granodiorite and tonalite representing by far the most representative rocks of the 

supersuite (Fig. 3.5). The composition of the intermediate and acid rocks of the G1 Supersuite is 

strongly variable, they are both magnesian and ferroan (Fig. 3.6a), metaluminous and peraluminous 

and from calcic to alkali-calcic (Figs. 3.6b and 3.6c). The Opx-bearing rocks are essentially 

magnesian, while the ETG and GT rocks range from magnesian to ferroan compositions (Fig. 3.6a). 

The ETG rocks are calcic, whilst the GT and Opx-bearing rocks cover from calcic to alkali-calcic 

compositions (Fig. 3.6b). The Opx-bearing rocks are dominantly metaluminous, with one exception

(sample L222), which is peraluminous (A/CNK = 1.20), whilst the GT and ETG rocks plot into the

When compiled the geochemical dataset of the G1 granitoids, the diagrams show that the great 

majority of the rocks are magnesian (~ 80%), metaluminous to slightly peraluminous (~ 84%) and 

between calcic and calc-alkalic (~ 83%) (Figs. 3.6a-c). The gabbroic rocks plot mostly on the calc-

alkaline field (Fig. 3.6d). 

The Opx-bearing rocks have SiO2 content ranging from 56.44 wt.% to 66.61 wt.%, whilst for 

the ETG and GT rocks the SiO2 content varies from 63.98 wt.% to 72.80 wt.%, and from 62.69 wt.% 

to 76.18 wt.%, respectively (Fig. 3.7, and Table 3.2). The K2O content is between 0.86 wt.% and 4.39 

wt.% for the Opx-bearing rocks, between 1.01 wt.% and 3.63 wt.% for the ETG rocks, and between 

2.58 wt.% and 6.25 wt.% for the GT rocks (Table 3.2). The highest CaO content of 6.82 wt.% was 

observed in the Opx-bearing rock group (sample L243), while the lowest value of 1.15 wt.% (sample 

L197) was obtained in the GT rock group. A slightly positive correlation between SiO2 and K2O is 

displayed by all rock groups (Fig. 3.7a). A clear negative correlation between CaO and SiO2, as well 

as between V and SiO2 could be observed (Figs. 3.7b and 3.7c). On the other hand, a slightly negative 

correlation between Ni and SiO2, and Sr and SiO2 could be observed for all rock groups (Fig. 3.7c, 

3.7d and 3.7f). The highest V (168 ppm), and Ni (31.2 ppm) contents were obtained in the rocks of the 

Opx-bearing group, samples L243 and L222, respectively (Table 3.2). The highest Sr (641.8 ppm), 

and the lowest Sr (159 ppm) contents were obtained in the rocks of the Opx-bearing group (sample 

L222), and of the GT group (sample L197), respectively (Table 3.2). No clear correlation could be 

observed between SiO2 and Rb, although a general positive correlation could be inferred (Fig. 3.7e). 

When compared with literature data on the Rio Doce arc, the geochemical dataset shows that 

the Opx-bearing rocks record the greatest chemical variability, with SiO2 ranging from 53.8 wt.% to 

74.6 wt.%, maficity (Fe + Mg) from 0.02 to 0.24 (Fig. 6c) and K2O from 0.9 wt.% to 7.3 wt.% (Fig. 

3.7a). A significant percentage (~ 40%) of the Opx-bearing rocks plots in the field of alkali-calcic 

rocks (Fig. 3.6b). They show Mg# ranging from 0.22 to 0.58, and are particularly enriched in V and Ni 

with respect to the other described lithologies (Figs. 3.7c and 3.7d). The GT and ETG rocks have SiO2 

content varying from 59.4 wt.% to 76.2 wt.%. At similar SiO2 contents, GT rocks have higher K2O 

and lower CaO than ETG rocks (Figs. 3.7a and 3.7b), thus the former have higher MALI (Na2O + K2O 

– CaO), with ~ 28 % and ~ 39 % of samples plotting in the calc-alkalic and alkali-calcic fields, 

respectively (Fig. 3.6b). The GT and ETG rocks show Mg# values that range between 0.05 and 0.55, 

which are similar to values found for Opx-bearing rocks. 

The GT, ETG and Opx-bearing rocks display similar REE patterns characterized by 

enrichment in LREE over HREE with (La/Yb)N ratios ranging mainly between ~ 4 and ~ 47. Figures

U-Pb GEOCHRONOLOGY  

Previous U-Pb zircon geochronological studies in the area between the towns of Governador 

Valadares and Ipanema (Fig. 3.2) have been limited to a small number of samples: one from the G5 

Supersuite (Petitgirard et al. 2009), one from the G2 Supersuite (Nalini Jr. 1997), two from the G1 

Supersuite (Nalini Jr. 1997, Petitgirard et al. 2009), and two from the meta-volcanics of the Rio Doce 

Group (Vieira 2007) (Fig. 3.2). In this study we have focused on the age of the surrounding basement 

which may have contributed to the G1 magmatism. We analyzed five rock samples: three samples 

from the basement rocks, as well as one from the Opx-bearing rocks and one from the mafic enclaves 

within the ETG group. 

  

Basement rocks (samples 247, 17A and 17B) 

Sample 247 (UTM 807430/7842740) was collected in the southwestern region of the study 

area from an enderbite that belong to the Juiz de Fora Complex. The enderbite is greenish fine- to 

medium-grained and shows an isotropic aspect (Figs. 3.9a and 3.9b). Samples 17A and 17B (UTM 

266028/7857896) were collected close to each other from a fine- to medium-grained banded 

orthogneiss that belongs to the Pocrane complex, in the central eastern region of the study area (Fig. 

3.2). The orthogneiss is characterized by alternating leucocratic and melanocratic bands ranging from 

cm- to metric wide (Fig. 3.9c). The leucocratic band consists predominantly of quartz and feldspar, 

whilst the melanocratic band is made up of hornblende and biotite, which define the rock foliation. 

The accessory assemblage is composed of zircon, apatite, titanite, epidote and occasionally garnet.    

The zircon grains extracted from these samples (samples 247, 17A and 17B) are very similar 

and comprise long-prismatic and large elongate grains (up to 400 ?m), with length/width ratios 

predominantly of 3:1, although higher ratios up to 4:1 are observed. They are light-gray and most 

zircon grains display magmatic oscillatory zoning with no inherited cores on CL images (Fig. 3.10a). 

However, some of the grains show roundish or embayment cores with visible truncation with the 

surrounding oscillatory rims. Several attempts to date these cores have failed and no coherent age data 

could be obtained. Most grains have Th/U ratios ranging from 0.20 to 0.76, which are indicative of a 

magmatic origin. Sometimes, these grains show corroded boundaries, however no metamorphic 

overgrowth was observed.  

Twenty spots obtained in the same number of zircon grains of the sample 247 yielded upper 

intercept at 2116 ± 13 Ma and lower intercept at 638 ± 38 Ma (MSWD = 2.1) (Fig. 3.11a). The upper 

intercept age is interpreted as the best approximation of the magmatic crystallization age of this 

sample. Fifty spots obtained from cores and rims of 25 zircon crystals for the sample 17A yielded 

upper intercept at 2102 ± 8 Ma and lower intercept at 420 ± 120 Ma (MSWD = 3.9) (Fig. 3.11b). The

DISCUSSION  

The G1 Supersuite, as exposed between the towns of Governador Valadares and Ipanema in 

eastern Minas Gerais, consists of three distinct associations of granitic rocks: the Opx-bearing, enclave 

rich and enclave poor rock groups. The Opx-bearing group is composed of predominantly green-

grayish tonalitic rocks, mostly poor in enclaves. The enclave-rich rocks (ETG group) consist of light 

to dark gray tonalites and granodiorites, crowded of centimetric to metric-sized melanocratic to 

mesocratic enclaves. The enclave-poor rocks (GT group) are made up of light gray granites to 

tonalites, with rare occurrence of enclaves.  

The geochemical signature of 7 samples of the Opx-bearing group revealed that it is composed 

of magnesian (Figs. 3.5 and 3.6a), calcic to alkali-calcic (Fig. 3.6b), predominantly metaluminous 

tonalites (Fig. 3.6c). Similar to a calc-alkaline series (Fig. 3.6d), the rocks of this group are less 

evolved, in terms of the SiO2 content, than the components of ETG and GT groups (Fig. 3.7). The 

Opx-bearing rocks have SiO2 content in average of 61.50 wt.%, whilst the ETG and GT have SiO2 

content in average of 68.32 wt.% and 70.31 wt.%, respectively (Table 3.2). The geochemical 

characteristics of the rocks belonging to the ETG group (10 samples) and GT group (8 samples) 

largely overlap. These rocks are magnesian to ferroan (Fig. 3.6a), predominantly calcic (Fig. 3.6b) and 

ranging from metaluminous to peraluminous terms (Fig. 3.6c).  

The geochemical data presented here show that these granitoids are mostly magnesian, calc-

alkalic to alkali-calcic, metaluminous to slightly peraluminous, and have a typical calc-alkaline trend, 

thus compositionally similar to other Cordilleran-type granitoids worldwide (e.g., Frost et al. 2001, 

Frost & Frost 2008, and references therein).   

Even though the study area does not cover the whole arc, it is clear that the analyzed samples 

cover the entire geochemical diversity shown by the Rio Doce arc rocks (Figs. 3.5 to 3.7). In this 

sense, ~150 samples from the literature (from published and unpublished data, see supplementary data 

item 1 for reference details) are now grouped according to the three rock groups here defined, based 

on field, petrographic and mainly the geochemical criteria. Therefore the initial 25 analyzed samples 

translate to: 43 geochemical analyses of rocks belonging to the Opx-bearing group, 70 analyses of 

rocks of the ETG group, 20 analyses of rocks of the GT rock group, as well as 22 analyses of enclaves 

and 14 analyses of gabbroic rocks. 

Our new zircon U-Pb data belonging to the Opx-bearing group (sample 242), an enclave 

within the ETG group (sample 3), and the Rhyacian basement rocks (samples 247 and 17A and 17B) 

are in good agreement with previous data available to the pre-collisional G1 magmatism (630-580 

Ma), as well as to the basement (~ 2100 Ma) of the Rio Doce arc (Nalini Jr. et al. 2000, Noce et al. 

2000, Silva et al. 2002, 2005, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Figueiredo 2009, Gonçalves 2009, Novo et 

al. 2010, Petitgirard et al. 2009, Mondou et al. 2012, Novo 2013, Tedeschi 2013). 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 63 

The three main groups range from acidic to intermediate igneous rocks (Table 3.3), and 

display similar U-Pb zircon crystallization ages (ca. 580-600 Ma). The available data only allow us to 

discuss possible petrogenetic processes under a regional perspective, as the studied rock groups do not 

represent individual plutons but composite batholithic masses (Fig. 3.2). Determining the unequivocal 

origin and source rocks of the Rio Doce arc may not be possible, due to the large range in composition 

and age of the rocks (630-580 Ma) forming this arc (Figueiredo & Campos-Neto 1993, Nalini Jr. et al. 

2005, Pedrosa-Soares & Wiedemann-Leonardos 2000, De Campos et al. 2004, Martins et al. 2004, 

Gonçalves et al. 2010, Novo et al. 2010, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011).   

Regionally, the granitic rocks forming plutons of the G1 Supersuite range in composition from 

diorite to alkali-granite, and their Opx-bearing equivalents, being predominant tonalite to granodiorite 

rocks (Fig. 3.5). The individualized rock groups follow the positive correlation for K and Rb, and the 

negative tendency for Ca, V, Ni and Sr against SiO2 content. Indeed, the occurrence of diorites and 

gabbros suggest the involvement of mantle-derived magmas in the genesis of the G1 Supersuite 

(Nalini Jr. et al. 2000, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011). However, the large petrographic and chemical 

variability characterizing the G1 granitic rocks, together with their large emplacement age range, 

suggest that different processes are likely to have contributed to shape the chemical composition of the 

supersuite, with the relative importance of these processes varying substantially for distinct plutons 

and batholiths. 

Among possible petrologic processes (e.g., Pitcher 1997, Annen & Sparks 2002, Chappel 

2004, Annen et al. 2006, Clemens et al. 2011, Clemens & Stevens 2012, Farina et al. 2012), we focus 

on the following main possibilities: i) fractional crystallization of mantle-derived magmas of gabbroic 

composition with assimilation of host rock as these magmas rose through the crust and emplaced, the 

so-called MASH process (melting, assimilation, storage and homogenization of deep crustal hot zones 

near the crust–mantle boundary); ii) mixing between crust- and mantle-derived magmas, with mafic 

enclaves representing evidence to support this process; iii) partial melting of plutonic sources with 

intermediate to acidic composition, relatively rich in biotite and hornblende. 

It is worth noting that these three models have a strong implication on the mechanisms of 

formation of continental crust. In fact, the amount of juvenile magmas involved in the three scenarios 

is drastically different. According to the first process the G1 Supersuite would represent a major event 

of net crustal growth, while following the last hypothesis the amount of juvenile crust formed is only 

minor and the supersuite would comprise recycling outcomes from older continental crust. The second 

hypothesis stands between these end-members and represents a combination of the MASH and crustal 

melting processes. Actually, these processes have been proposed to occur simultaneously, with heat 

and H2O released from the crystallizing primary magmas acting as the trigger for the crustal melting 

(Annen & Sparks 2002).

 64 

Table 3.3 – Main features of the rocks forming the G1 Supersuite. 

 

Evolution of mantle-derived magmas 

The efficacy of MASH depends on the efficient co-functioning of fractional crystallization, 

assimilation and magma mixing. Although this model may be involved at some extent in the 

generation of the G1 Supersuite, there are three lines of evidence arguing against MASH to explain the 

chemical diversity of the G1 Supersuite. 

Firstly, the Sr and Nd isotopic composition available for the G1 Supersuite is typically crustal 

in signature (Nalini Jr. 1997, Martins et al. 2004, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011), although this may be 

accepted for continental magmatic arcs. In particular, Novo et al. (2010) analyzed the Nd isotopic 

signature (epsilon Nd = -10; TDM model age ~ 2 Ga) of two 600 Ma Opx-bearing rocks of intermediate 

composition (SiO2 = 54 to 57 %) and relatively low-K contents (K2O/Na2O+CaO = 0.16 to 1.3), 

concluding for an important involvement of the Rhyacian granulitic basement in the origin of the 

Divino Suite. However, this suite also includes abundant gabbroic and dioritic rocks, pointing to 

significant mantle contribution, and an expanded high-K calc-alkaline signature and correlations in 

Harker diagrams suggesting fractional crystallization (Novo et al. 2010). 

Sr and Nd isotopic composition of eight samples from four tonalite-granodiorite samples of 

the G1 Supersuite exposed in the northern part of the arc have variable negative Nd values (-5.6 to -

12.9) but relatively constant (
87

Sr/
86

Sr)i values (0.710 to 0.709) (Martins et al. 2004). Sr and Nd data 

from five ETG samples from the Galiléia batholith (granodiorites, tonalites and enclaves sampled near 

the town of Conselheiro Pena) also record negative Nd values (-8.3 to -9.3) and relatively similar 

(
87

86

Sr)i values (0.712 to 0.713) (Nalini Jr. 1997). Although assimilation of crustal rocks by the 

primary magmas may drive the composition of mantle-derived magmas toward higher

lower 
143

144

Nd, the crustal signature described for the reported samples requires large volumes of 

assimilated crust. This is in contrast with the existence of thermal limitations on the incorporations of 

whole-rock material into basaltic magmas (Glazner 2007). In fact, the energy consumed in this 

processes results in considerable cooling, crystallization and formation of hybrid magmas that are so 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 65 

highly crystallized to become immobile and incapable of undergoing further magmatic evolution 

(Clemens & Stevens 2012). On the other hand, our samples were collected from tonalites and 

granodiorites rich in gabbroic to dioritic enclaves, which suggest contribution from mantelic magma. 

Secondly, assuming that plagioclase and orthopyroxene are the main minerals to fractionate 

from the gabbroic primary magma, gabbros involved in fractional crystallization should be 3 or 4 

times more voluminous than the co-genetic granitoids with production of significant volumes of 

cumulatic gabbros (Fig. 3.12). In fact, there is no record of such cumulatic rocks in the G1 Supersuite. 

However, we cannot exclude that these rocks have not been found due to the lack of detailed studies 

on individual plutons, or that they were delaminated, due to their high density, in the collisional to 

post-collisional stages of evolution of the Araçuaí orogen. 

Finally, plagioclase (Pl) and orthopyroxene (Opx) fractionation do not account for the great 

chemical diversity shown by the G1 Supersuite (Figs. 3.12a and 3.12b). Assuming that the chemical 

composition of the primary magma of the G1 Supersuite could be that of a gabbroic rock (sample T1 

from an outcrop in the southern portion of the arc; Novo 2009, Novo et al. 2010), it would be 

necessary to fractionate large proportions of Pl and Opx or even Pl and olivine (Ol) to reach the end-

acid members (Figs. 3.12a and 3.12b). Indeed, using CaO and maficity as fractionation markers, 

crystallization larger than ~ 20% Pl and ~ 20% Opx would not fit the G1 Supersuite trend for both 

markers (Figs. 3.12a and 3.12b). This proportion would be even lower considering the synchronous Pl 

and Ol crystallization, ~ 5% and ~ 4%, respectively (Fig. 3.12a and 3.12b).  

Fractional crystallization has been postulated as a first-order mechanism controlling the 

magmatic evolution of the G1 Galiléia batholith (Nalini Jr. et al. 2005). Although such process may 

play an important role for the evolution of single plutons (Nalini Jr. et al. 2005, Novo et al. 2010), 

there is no evidence, in a regional scale, to consider fractional crystallization as a first-order 

mechanism to explain the chemical diversity shown by the G1 Supersuite. 

 

Magma mixing and mingling 

The occurrence of mafic bodies such as synplutonic dykes, pillows and enclaves in 

intermediate to felsic host rocks is commonly considered a strong evidence supporting hybridization 

between highly felsic melts from the continental crust and mantle-derived magmas to produce 

granodiorite and tonalite in many different tectonic settings (e.g., Pitcher 1991). The widespread 

occurrence of mafic enclaves within most G1 plutons, and the occurrence of gabbroic plutons in the 

rock record of the G1 Supersuite indicate the involvement of mantle-derived magmas in the genesis of 

the supersuite. However, the real conundrum is to establish how and to what extent these mantle-

derived magmas influenced the composition of the volumetrically dominant granitoid magma in the

The importance of this process may vary substantially from pluton to pluton (e.g. Nalini Jr. et 

al. 2005, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011). Therefore, an estimation of the role of mantle-derived magmas 

in the origin of the G1 Supersuite would imply detailed studies on selected areas and would strongly 

rely on isotopic data that are not available. 

  

Recycling the basement rocks 

The G1 rocks intrude the Rhyacian orthogneisses of the Juiz de Fora and Pocrane complexes. 

The ca. 2.1 Ga U-Pb ages from this study, as well as published ages (Machado et al. 1996, Silva et al. 

2011, Noce et al. 2007, Heilbron et al. 2010) clearly pin point the Pocrane and Juiz de Fora complexes 

as part of the Rhyacian component of the basement of the Araçuaí orogen. The granitoids of the G1 

Supersuite, as well as some mafic enclaves hosted within them, contain large amounts of ca. 2.1 Ga 

inherited zircon grains that are possibly related to the Juiz de Fora and Pocrane rocks (Table 3.1; Fig. 

3.11f). Thus, U-Pb crystallization and inherited ages presented here and in previous studies indicate a 

close association between G1 granitic rocks and the Rhyacian orthogneisses that make up the 

continental basement of the Rio Doce arc. 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 67 

The U-Pb information complements the isotope data suggesting that rocks of the Rhyacian 

basement contributed for the genesis of G1 granitoids. The occurrence of mafic enclaves within 

tonalite-to-granite plutons, as well as the occurrence of gabbroic plutons indicates the initial 

involvement of mantle-derived magmas. However, it is worth noting that the SiO2 and maficity (Fe + 

Mg) content of ETG and GT largely overlaps, suggesting that the difference between the two groups is 

unlikely to be produced by different degrees of interaction with a mantle-derived end-member.  

The rocks forming the ETG and GT groups show overall chemical characteristics of I-type 

granitoids (e.g. Farina et al. 2012):  a decrease in ASI with increasing maficity (Fig. 3.6c) as well as a 

negative correlation between CaO content and SiO2 (Fig. 3.7b). These characteristics have been 

recently interpreted by Clemens et al. (2011) as resulting from biotite and hornblende partial melting 

of immature sediments with andesitic/dacitic composition and entrainment of a peritectic assemblage 

mostly constituted of pyroxene and plagioclase. The main difference between the ETG and GT groups 

is their alkali content, with GT rocks being significantly more K2O-rich than ETG rocks at similar 

SiO2. Partial melting experiments on metapelites and metagreywackes show how the K and Na content 

in granitic magmas reflect the stoichiometry of the melting reactions and the chemistry of the source 

(Farina et al. 2012). In particular, the K:Na of partial melts is related to the variability of the 

biotite/plagioclase ratio in the melting reaction, (biotite is the main K-bearing phase) as well as 

plagioclase composition (plagioclase is the main Na-bearing phase) in the source. 

We suggest that the difference between the K2O content of ETG and GT may reflect: 1) the 

occurrence of two different fertile protoliths in the crust during the genesis of the magmatic arc; 2) 

different heating cycle between two areas broadly characterized by the same sources. This latter 

hypothesis is based on the evidence that fluid-absent melting of biotite typically begins at temperatures 

around 830 °C (at 0.5 GPa; Stevens et al. 1997) while temperatures as high as 900 °C are required for 

hornblende melting (Skjerlie & Patiño Douce 1995). According to the first hypothesis, partial melting 

of a biotite-hornblende source with intermediate composition was involved in the magmatism of the 

ETG rocks, while GT rocks show the contribution of mostly biotite fluid-absent melting of a more 

mature source with little contribution from hornblende melting. Alternatively, the heating cycle below 

ETG rocks allow temperature as high as 900 °C to be achieved and maintained enhancing coupled 

biotite and hornblende melting, while lower temperatures were reached in the crust below GT rocks.  

This second interpretation is in agreement with the large amount of mafic enclaves in the ETG rocks, 

while GT rocks are poor or free in mafic enclaves. In fact, the mafic enclaves can witness underplating 

of mantle-derived magmas producing higher and more persistent temperature anomalies. 

The composition of GT rocks is much more variable than that of ETG granitoids with some of 

the GT rocks showing enrichment in K and Rb and others displaying extremely high Sr content (Figs. 

3.7a, 3.7e and 3.7f). This second-order variability within the individual identified lithotypes suggests 

that different petrogenetic processes have contributed to shape the composition of the G1 rocks. 



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 68 

Accordingly, although detailed calculations of crystal fractionation and assimilation-fractional 

crystallization processes for the G1 Supersuite is out of the scope of this work, we present a general 

hypothesis for the petrogenesis of the Rio Doce magmatic arc. In this approximation partial melting 

processes are favored, although we believe that an unequivocal origin for the magmas responsible for 

the evolution and development of the Rio Doce arc is a challengeable work, still to be done.  

 

The charnockites forming the G1 Supersuite 

The intermediate to felsic (charnockitic) Opx-bearing plutonic rocks of the G1 Supersuite 

exhibit strongly variable chemical composition ranging from magnesian to ferroan and from calcic to 

alkalic (Figs. 3.6a and 3.6b). However, most of the charnockites are magnesian, calc-alkalic to alkali-

calcic and metaluminous, thus compositionally similar to Cordilleran batholiths (Frost & Frost 2008). 

The overall arc-like major and trace element compositions of the Opx-bearing rocks of the G1 

Supersuite suggest that these charnockites represent the roots of the Rio Doce magmatic arc. The 

capacity of granitic magmas to dissolve and react with orthopyroxene during ascent, causing early, 

anhydrous, ferromagnesian minerals to be supplanted by hornblende and biotite, is related to the 

increase in aH2O and aK2O taking place in the magma during crystallization. This observation lead 

Frost et al. (1989) to conclude that if pyroxenes are to survive in a granitoid, charnockites must 

represent cumulates that formed early in the crystallization of a pluton, and were isolated from later, 

more hydrous portions of the batholith. However, the composition of the Opx-rocks of the G1 

Supersuite is significantly scattered, with poor or absent positive linear correlations within the 

elements hosted in the early crystallizing phases (i.e., orthopyroxene and plagioclase) favoring other 

processes rather than fractional crystallization for the genesis of these rocks. The crustal Sr and Nd 

isotopic signature displayed by the charnockites of the G1 Supersuite led us to suggest, following 

Young et al. (1997), that high-temperature partial melting of dry and largely restitic, granulitic crustal 

sources may have been contributed for its genesis. 

 

Conclusions 

Field and petrographic observations, geochemistry and geochronology of one of the best 

exposed segments of the Rio Doce arc, combined with geochemical/isotopic data from the literature, 

led us to the following conclusions: 

1. The Ediacaran continental Rio Doce magmatic arc of the Araçuaí orogen comprises a great 

diversity of rocks. In the study area, the rocks range from diorites to alkali granites with tonalite and 

granodiorite representing by far the most representative rocks of the arc. Three rock groups could be 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 69 

distinguished, namely: Opx-bearing rocks, enclave-rich tonalite-granodiorite (ETG), and enclave-poor 

granite to tonalite (GT).  

2. The Rio Doce magmatic arc consists mostly of granitoids chemically similar to a series of 

magnesian, calc-alkalic to alkali-calcic, metaluminous to slightly peraluminous, which are 

compositionally similar to Cordilleran-type granitoids worldwide. 

3. U-Pb zircon ages reveal that, in the study area, the rocks forming the Rio Doce arc 

crystallized between 597 and 581 Ma, with ages roughly around 2.1 Ga obtained from inherited cores 

of zircon proving that a Rhyacian continental crust may be involved in the G1 rocks production. These 

results are in good agreement with the current literature about the Araçuaí orogen, particularly 

regarding the early development stages responsible for the building of its magmatic arc, the 

continental Rio Doce magmatic arc. 

4. Key chemical and mineralogical features suggest that different igneous processes may be 

involved in the development of the Rio Doce arc. These processes are: i) fractional crystallization of 

mantle-derived magmas of gabbroic composition with assimilation of host rock as these magmas rose 

through the crust and emplaced; ii) mixing between crust- and mantle-derived magmas, with mafic 

enclaves representing evidence to support this process; iii) partial melting of plutonic sources with 

intermediate to acidic composition, relatively rich in biotite and hornblende. In the light of the present 

knowledge it is impossible to evaluate the real contribution of each one of the mentioned process. 

Most likely, playing different roles in distinct portions of the crust they compete during the formation 

of the Rio Doce arc.

3.3 

FROM THE PLUTONIC ROOT TO THE VOLCANIC ROOF OF A 

CONTINENTAL MAGMATIC ARC: AN EXAMPLE FROM THE 

NEOPROTEROZOIC ARAÇUAÍ OROGEN, SOUTHEASTERN BRAZIL
1
 

ABSTRACT 

The Araçuaí orogen of southeastern Brazil corresponds to the largest portion of the Araçuaí-West 

Congo orogen (AWCO), one of the various components of the Brasiliano/Pan-African orogenic network 

generated during the amalgamation of West Gondwana. In the reconstructions of Gondwana, the AWCO, 

encompassing the Araçuaí orogen of South America and the West Congo belt of Southwestern Africa, appears as 

a tongue-shaped orogenic zone embraced by the São Francisco-Congo craton. Although AWCO differs from the 

vast majority of the known orogens owing to its singular confined setting, it contains a large amount of orogenic 

igneous rocks emplaced in all stages of its tectonic evolution, from the Early Ediacaran to the Early Ordovician. 

In this study, we provide new information about the oldest Ediacaran granitic assemblage, the G1 Supersuite, 

which together with the Rio Doce Group materializes the Rio Doce magmatic arc. Field relationships and 

mineralogical compositions of the G1 Supersuite allowed us to characterize three lithofacies associations, which 

are a zone with Opx-bearing rocks, enclave-rich Tonalite-Granodiorite and enclave-poor Granite to Tonalite, 

suggesting different crustal levels exposed in the central part of the Araçuaí orogen. This region seems thus to be 

a tilted crustal section, with deep arc roots now exposed along its western border. Chemically, these plutonic 

associations consist mostly of magnesian, metaluminous to slightly peraluminous, calc-alkaline to alkali-calcic 

and medium- to high-K acidic rocks. On the other hand, the dacitic and rhyolitic rocks of the Rio Doce Group 

are mainly magnesian, peraluminous, calcic to calc-alkaline and medium- to high-K acidic rocks. New zircon U-

Pb data constrain the crystallization of the granitic plutonic rocks between ca. 625 and 579 Ma, while the ages 

for the metavolcanic rocks range between ca. 585 and 578 Ma. Thus, within errors, the studied plutonic and 

volcanic rocks might belong to the same magmatic event. This event, predating (with some overlap) the ages of 

emplacement of syn-collisional, S-type granites, might represent the subduction-related, pre-collisional, event 

that took place in the Araçuaí orogen. In addition, whole-rock Sm-Nd isotopic compositions show variable 

negative ?Nd(t) values between -13.07 and -6.52, and TDM model ages varying from 1.51 Ga to 1.87 Ga. Thus, 

predominantly constructed upon a Rhyacian magmatic arc from 630 Ma to 580 Ma, the Rio Doce arc shows 

crustal melts largely prevailing over mantle magmas, providing a well-studied example to be compared with 

similar orogenic settings around the world.

INTRODUCTION 

Continental magmatic arcs developed in close association with subduction systems involve up 

to 50 km-thick magmatic sections composed essentially of tonalite to granodiorite, and their volcanic 

equivalents (see Ducea et al. 2015a for a comprehensive review). The active margins of the Americas 

contain the best studied arc-related magmatic edifices (e.g., Winter 2001, Ducea et al. 2015a and 

references therein). Tectonic shortening acting upon various sectors of the Americas  ? Pacific margin 

caused uplift and crustal tilting, promoting exposure of thick and deep magmatic arc sections. Well-

exposed sections from the roots to roofs of Phanerozoic magmatic arcs have been documented, for 

example, in southern California (North American Cordillera; Barth et al. 2008) and in the Sierra de 

Valle Fértil of central Argentina (Andean chain; Otamendi et al. 2012). Accordingly, one can expected 

that, under favorable circumstances, Precambrian magmatic arcs also can be examined from their deep 

roots up to their volcano-sedimentary roofs. 

In this paper, we present the results of a detailed structural, petrological and geochronological 

investigation of an approximately 30 km-thick crustal section, which comprises, from base to the top, 

a succession of enderbites, tonalites, granodiorites, and acid lavas intercalated with metasedimentary 

rocks. Exposed in the crystalline core of the Neoproterozoic Araçuaí orogen in southeastern Brazil, 

this rock assemblage represents, according to our interpretation, a section of a continental magmatic 

arc, developed in the Ediacaran period between 625 and 578 Ma. 

The Araçuaí orogen of southeastern Brazil corresponds to the largest portion of the Araçuaí-

West Congo orogen (AWCO), one of the various components of the Brasiliano/Pan-African orogenic 

network generated during the amalgamation of West Gondwana by the end of the Ediacaran Period 

(Trompette 1994, Brito Neves et al. 1999, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2001, Cordani et al. 2003, Alkmim et 

al. 2006, Bento dos Santos et al. 2015). In the reconstructions of Gondwana, the AWCO, 

encompassing the Araçuaí orogen and its counterpart of southwestern Africa, the West Congo belt, 

appears as a tongue-shaped orogenic zone embraced by the São Francisco-Congo craton (Figs. 3.13 

and 3.14). Despite this singular confined setting, AWCO involves lithological assemblages that 

indicate a precursor basin similar to a modern inland-sea basin partially floored by oceanic crust, 

representing a terminal branch of the Neoproterozoic Adamastor Ocean. The closure of this basin, 

known as the Macaúbas basin, started around the Cryogenian-Ediacaran boundary, driven by the 

subduction of oceanic lithosphere (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 1998, 2001, Alkmim et al. 2006, Queiroga et 

al. 2007, Kuchenbecker et al. 2015). 

Although AWCO differs from the vast majority of the known orogens, it contains a large 

amount of orogenic igneous rocks emplaced in all stages of its tectonic evolution, from the Early 

Ediacaran to the Early Ordovician (Fig. 3.14). The oldest Ediacaran granitic assemblage, the G1 

Supersuite, consists mainly of tonalites and granodiorites dated between 630 and 580 Ma (Nalini Jr. 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 73 

Figure 3.13 - Relative positions of the Neoproterozoic orogenic belts (in gray) presently exposed along the South 

American and African margins of the Atlantic, in the geotectonic scenario of West Gondwana (modified from 

Porada 1989). 

 

1997, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2001, 2011, Martins et al. 2004, Novo et al. 2010, Gonçalves et al. 2014, 

2015, Tedeschi et al. 2015). The G1 granitic rocks intrude the Paleoproterozoic basement of the 

central portion of the orogen, thereby defining a roughly NS-trending belt of multiple plutons, partially 

covered by sedimentary and volcanic rocks of the Rio Doce Group (e.g., Vieira 2007, Pedrosa-Soares 

et al. 2008, 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014) (Fig. 3.15). According to Pedrosa-Soares et al. (2011), the 

G1 Supersuite together with the Rio Doce Group materialize the Rio Doce magmatic arc, a product of 

subduction-related magmatism that took place during closure of the Macaúbas basin oceanic sector. 

The purpose of this paper is twofold. First, we present new structural, petrological, isotopic 

and geochronological data on the G1 Supersuite and associated rock assemblages, which provides 

further evidence for the generation of the G1 granitic assemblage in an arc setting and basis for testing 

the models postulated for the development of the AWCO in the scenario of Gondwana assembly. 

Second, by discussing the results of our study in the light of literature data on ancient and modern 

magmatic arcs, we hope to contribute with the discussion on the nature and structure of magmatic arc 

edifices generated in orogenic continental settings, especially in those similar to a confined orogen like 

the AWCO.

GEOLOGICAL SETTING OF THE ARAÇUAÍ OROGEN CENTRAL PORTION 

 

The Araçuaí orogen, located between the São Francisco craton and the eastern Brazilian 

continental margin (Fig. 3.14), consists of a metamorphic fold-thrust belt in the external zone, and a 

crystalline core mostly composed of high-grade metamorphic rocks and granitoids. These domains 

include a basement made up of Archean and Paleoproterozoic units, Neoproterozoic sedimentary and 

volcanic rocks, and a large volume of orogenic plutonic rocks (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2001, 2008, 

Alkmim et al. 2006, Noce et al. 2007, Kuchenbecker et al. 2015, Peixoto et al. 2015). Those plutonic 

rocks cover an area of 350,000 km
2
 in the crystalline core of the Araçuaí orogen. They are mostly 

granitoids that have been grouped into five supersuites (G1 to G5), formed in the pre-collisional, 

collisional and post-collisional stages of development of the orogen, from ca. 630 Ma to ca. 480 Ma 

(Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014, 2015, Gradim et al. 2014, 2015, Tedeschi et al. 

2015) (Fig. 3.14). 

The area focused in our study, encompassing a segment of ca. 10,000 km
2
 of the crystalline 

core of the Araçuaí orogen, is located between the towns of Governador Valadares and Ipanema in 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 75 

northeastern Minas Gerais state, Brazil, being limited by the coordinates 18º50’ and 19º50’ S. Lat., 

and 42º10’ and 41º20’ W. Long. (Figs. 3.14 and 3.15). This area was selected for study because it 

contains many of the best exposures of both the G1 Supersuite and Rio Doce Group, allowing the 

investigation of their general attributes and relationships with other lithotectonic assemblages and 

structures of the Araçuaí orogen. Below we provide a brief description of rock assemblages and 

structures of the central sector of Araçuaí orogen. 

 

 Lithological assemblages 

Besides the G1 Supersuite and Rio Doce Group, focus of this study, the area selected for 

investigation also exposes the Rhyacian basement, Neoproterozoic metasedimentary and metavolcanic 

rocks, and Ediacaran to early Cambrian granites of the G2 and G5 supersuites (Fig. 3.15).  

The Rhyacian basement comprises the Juiz de Fora and Pocrane complexes. The Juiz de Fora 

Complex, composed essentially of gray-greenish charnockitic gneiss, occurs in the hanging wall of the 

Abre Campo shear zone (ACSZ), a major thrust, which is considered to be the suture zone of the 

orogen (Cunningham et al. 1996, Brueckner et al. 2000, Peres et al. 2004, Alkmim et al. 2006, Noce 

et al. 2007, Silva et al. 2009) (Fig. 3.15). U-Pb age determinations on the Juiz de Fora gneisses 

constrain its crystallization between 2134 and 2084 Ma (Machado et al. 1996, Noce et al. 2007, 

Heilbron et al. 2010, Gonçalves et al. 2014). Its geochemical signature, positive ?Nd values and no 

inherited zircon grains characterizes a juvenile magmatic arc (Figueiredo & Teixeira 1996, Duarte et 

al. 1997, Fischel et al. 1998, Noce et al. 2007). 

The Pocrane Complex occurs in the core of a large fault-bounded antiformal structure that 

dominates the structural picture of the studied area (Fig. 3.15). Orthogneisses and paragneisses with 

meta-mafic and meta-ultramafic intercalations are the main rock types of this complex. U-Pb age 

determinations on the Pocrane orthogneisses have yielded crystallization ages between 2184 and 2086 

Ma (Novo 2013, Gonçalves et al. 2014). Again, positive ?Nd(t) values and no inherited zircon grains 

characterizes a rock-assemblage related to a juvenile magmatic arc (Novo 2013, Tedeschi 2013), 

which can be correlate to the Juiz de Fora arc. Therefore, the basement of the Rio Doce arc consists of 

a Rhyacian magmatic with an outstanding juvenile signature: The Juiz de Fora-Pocrane arc (Novo 

2013). 

Tonian to Ediacaran metasedimentary rocks forms a NS-trending belt in the footwall of the 

Abre Campo shear zone in the northwestern part of the study area (Fig. 3.15). The biotite and 

amphibole-rich mylonitic gneisses and schists containing tectonic slices of meta-ultramafic rocks, 

comprise two distinct units (Peixoto et al. 2015). The basal schist succession, with a maximum 

depositional age of 819 Ma, represents distal marine sediments (probably ocean floor deposits) of the 

Macaúbas Group, the type sedimentary unit of the orogen. The upper succession is a correlative of the

 77 

syn-orogenic Salinas Formation (Lima et al. 2002, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2008, Santos et al. 2009). 

Zircons extracted from this unit yielded a maximum deposition age of ca. 600 Ma, implying that its 

main sources were rocks of the G1 Supersuite and Rio Doce Group. According to Peixoto et al. 

(2015), this schist belt represents a fragment of an accretionary wedge, which besides deep marine 

sediments also involved slices of the oceanic lithosphere and syn-orogenic (flysch-type) deposits. 

The G1 Supersuite plutons define a ca. 55 km wide belt that extends for over 340 km between 

the towns of Teófilo Otoni and Juiz de Fora in Minas Gerais state. Rocks forming the plutons vary 

from gabbros to granites with tonalites and granodiorites representing by far the most common 

lithotypes (e.g., Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014, Tedeschi et al. 2015). The majority 

of the G1 rocks is metaluminous to slightly peraluminous with Aluminum Saturation Index (ASI) 

lower than 1.1. Taken together, the G1 rocks show similarity to an expanded calc-alkaline series (e.g., 

Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014, Tedeschi et al. 2015). Additionally, higher values 

of ASI are related to the lower maficity (Fe + Mg) numbers for G1 rocks, characterizing a typical 

trend of I-type granites (e.g., Clemens et al. 2011). The composition of the intermediate and acid rocks 

of the supersuite ranges from magnesian to ferroan and from calcic to alkali-calcic. Rocks showing 

magnesian and calcic to calc-alkaline compositions are, however, predominant (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 

2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014, Tedeschi et al. 2015). The main attributes and crystallization ages of the 

G1 plutons are summarized on Table 3.4. The oldest and youngest ages so far obtained for these 

granites are 625 ± 11 Ma and 576 ± 9 Ma, respectively (Paes 1999, Tedeschi et al. 2015). 

In the study area, the G1 Supersuite rocks form NS-elongated batholiths and stocks (Fig. 

3.15). They show distinct contacts with both the basement complexes and Rio Doce Group. Shear 

zones reveal tectonic contacts and aureoles of thermal metamorphism indicate intrusive contacts. 

Erosional contacts showing G1 rocks covered by metasedimentary and metavolcanic rocks of the Rio 

Doce Group can also be found elsewhere (Pinto et al. 2000, Vieira 2007, Gonçalves 2009, Novo 2013, 

Tedeschi 2013). 

The metavolcano-sedimentary succession of the Rio Doce Group includes, from the base to 

the top, the Palmital do Sul, Tumiritinga, São Tomé and João Pinto formations (Vieira 2007) (Fig. 

3.15). The Palmital do Sul Formation comprises pelitic schists to paragneisses, with intercalations of 

metavolcanic rocks of pyroclastic nature and dacitic to rhyolitic composition dated from ca. 585 Ma to 

ca. 595 Ma (Vieira 2007, Gonçalves 2009, Novo 2013). The Tumiritinga Formation includes an 

extensive package of quartz-mica schists with intercalations of quartz-feldspar-rich schists and calc-

silicate rocks. The quartz-feldspar-rich schists represent volcanoclastic rocks of dacitic composition. 

The age obtained for a record of volcanic activity related to the Tumiritinga Formation is 585 ± 4 Ma 

(zircon, U-Pb SHRIMP; Vieira 2007). The São Tomé Formation consists mainly of quartz-mica 

schists and metagreywackes, with a maximum depositional age around 594 Ma (U-Pb SHRIMP on 

detrital zircon grains; Vieira 2007). The uppermost unit of the Rio Doce Group is the João Pinto

Formation, made up of thick layers and lenses of quartzites with minor pelitic intercalations (Fig. 

3.15). 

Small plutons of the G2 Supersuite intrude all previously mentioned units, mainly in the 

northern half of the study area (Fig. 3.15). Consisting of foliated, fine to coarse grained garnet-

sillimanite and two-mica granites, the G2 intrusions of the study area were dated between 582 and 560 

Ma by the U-Pb TIMS method (Nalini Jr. 1997, Nalini Jr. et al. 2000). This age interval corresponds 

to the main phase of deformation and regional metamorphism in the Araçuaí orogen (Nalini Jr. 1997, 

Alkmim et al. 2006, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Silva et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014, Gradim et al. 

2014). 

A late igneous activity in the study area is represented by a thick sill composed of syenitic 

rocks, which occurs in the high slopes of the Ibituruna peak, near the town of Governador Valadares 

(Fig. 3.15). Petitgirard et al. (2009) obtained an age of 530 ± 1 Ma (zircon U-Pb, LA-ICP-MS) for the 

magmatic crystallization of the Ibiturana syenitic sill. This age post-date by more than 10 Ma the ages 

of the youngest plutons related to the collisional stage (Gradim et al. 2014, Peixoto et al. 2015, Richter 

et al. 2015), contradicting the interpretation, made by Petitgirard et al. (2009), that the Ibituruna sill 

was emplaced during the regional tectonic event and deformed before its complete solidification. 

 

Structure and metamorphism 

NS-trending thrust and strike-slip shear zones are the main structures of the focused area 

(Figs. 3.15 and 3.16). The NE-trending Abre Campo thrust shear zone, exposed in the northwestern 

portion of the study area (Fig. 3.15), brought Rhyacian metamorphic high grade orthogneisses of the 

Juiz de Fora Complex on top of lower grade Neoproterozoic schists of the forearc accretionary wedge 

(Cunningham et al. 1998, Peres et al. 2004, Alkmim et al. 2006, Silva et al. 2009, Peixoto et al. 2015). 

Firstly described as a geophysical discontinuity (Haralyi & Hasui 1982), this shear zone is marked by 

mylonites and augen gneisses that can be traced for at least 300 km, reaching widths of up to 5 km 

(Peres et al. 2004, Silva 2010). Silva (2010) subdivided the Abre Campo shear zone in three segments. 

The northern and preserved segment corresponds to a W-directed thrust zone. The central and southern 

were later deformed and converted into dextral strike-slip fault zones. 

Local studies, carried out by Nalini Jr. (1997), Paes (1999), Vieira (2007), Figueiredo (2009), 

Gonçalves (2009) and Novo (2009, 2013), describe a pervasive NS-trending, E-dipping foliation 

associated with a ENE-plunging stretching lineation, as well as strike-slip shear zones, as the main 

tectonic elements affecting the G1 rocks in the western to central region of the Rio Doce arc (Fig. 

3.15). These mylonitic shear zones trend preferentially NS to NNE with moderate to vertical dips, and 

the stretching lineation on the mylonitic foliation plunges 10º to 40º north and records a systematic 

dextral sense of shear (Cunningham et al. 1996, Nalini Jr. 1997, Féboli 2000, Peres et al. 2004, Vieira

2007, Figueiredo 2009, Gonçalves 2009, Novo 2009, Petitgirard et al. 2009, Mondou et al. 2012, 

Peixoto et al. 2015). 

The main regional foliation is materialized by metamorphic mineral assemblages recording PT 

conditions from the greenschist-amphibolite facies transition (e.g., in pelitic schists of the Rio Doce 

Group) to the granulite facies (e.g., in the Juiz de Fora Complex), including the amphibolite to 

granulite facies conditions recorded by G1 and G2 supersuites (Pereira & Zucchetti 2000, Munhá et al. 

2005, Vieira 2007, Noce et al. 2007, Gonçalves 2009, Novo 2009, 2013, Novo et al. 2010, Gonçalves 

et al. 2014, 2015, Gradim et al. 2014, Peixoto et al. 2015, Richter et al. 2015). 

In the study area, microprobe analyses carried out on garnet (Alm73Gro3Py14Sp10) and 

oligoclase (Ab78An22) from the Tumiritinga Formation indicated P-T conditions in the range of 468 ± 

50 ºC at 4.96 ± 1 kbar to 638 ± 76 ºC at 4.56 ± 1 kbar (Vieira 2007).

Despite the robust evidence that the regional foliation and associated stretching lineation 

developed in solid-state (ductile) conditions on G1 and G2 granitic rocks (Nalini Jr. 1997, Nalini Jr. et 

al. 2000, Oliveira et al. 2000, Alkmim et al. 2006, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2006, 2011, Nalini Jr. et al. 

2005, Gonçalves 2009, Novo 2009, 2013, Silva 2009, Novo et al. 2010, Tedeschi 2013, Gonçalves et 

al. 2014, 2015, Gradim et al. 2014, Peixoto et al. 2015, Richter et al. 2015), some authors have 

suggested that these structures resulted exclusively from magmatic flow (Egydio-Silva et al. 2007, 

Vauchez et al. 2007, Petitgirard et al. 2009, Mondou et al. 2012). 

 

NATURE AND STRUCTURE OF THE INVESTIGATED MAGMATIC CRUSTAL 

SECTION 

According to the mineralogical composition and field relationships, three distinct lithofacies 

associations of the G1 Supersuite have been discriminated in the study area, namely: i) zone with Opx-

bearing rocks, ii) enclave-rich Tonalite-Granodiorite, and iii) enclave-poor Granite to Tonalite (Fig. 

3.15). The volcanic members of the Rio Doce Group that occur in the same area correspond to dacitic 

and rhyolitic volcanoclastic rocks. 

 

Zone with Opx-bearing rocks 

Orthopyroxene-bearing granitoids occur in the Derribadinha batholith (Féboli 1997), which 

consists of enderbites, tonalites and granodiorites, with minor dioritic bodies. This batholith forms a 

NS-elongated thrust slice sandwiched between the Juiz de Fora and Pocrane basement complexes 

(Figs. 3.15 and 3.16). 

The enderbites are greenish and fine- to medium-grained and made up of orthopyroxene, 

clinopyroxene, hornblende and biotite, up to 30%, plagioclase (~25%), quartz (~30%) and microcline 

(~15%). Titanite, zircon, allanite, garnet, pyrrhotite, chalcopyrite, pyrite and pentlandite are common 

accessory minerals.  

The tonalites and granodiorites are mostly dark gray, fine- to medium-grained. These 

hornblende-biotite-bearing rocks have similar mineral assemblage to the enderbites, except for the 

pyroxenes. The transition from tonalites-granodiorites to enderbites is highlighted in the field by a 

difference in color. 

The diorites are mostly dark gray and fine- to medium-grained, consisting of plagioclase, 

hornblende, biotite, and minor quartz and orthopyroxene. The accessory assemblage is composed of 

apatite, zircon, ilmenite and magnetite. The foliation of these rocks is marked by the orientation of 

biotite and hornblende. 



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 82 

Melanocratic enclaves are present in all lithofacies of the association. Centimeter-thick 

leucocratic veins cut all members of the unit, being especially frequent in the tonalites and 

granodiorites. 

Rocks of this unit display either an isotropic aspect or a conspicuous foliation, marked by 

alignment of hornblende and/or biotite. The biotite is euhedral, brown-reddish, and occasionally 

product of hornblende breakdown. The hornblende is essentially anhedral, defining the rock foliation 

or even without shape preferred orientation. Igneous orthopyroxene is often partially replaced by 

hornblende and/or biotite (Fig. 3.17a). Clinozoisite is the more common secondary mineral, although 

muscovite and chlorite have been also observed. In the foliated enderbites, feldspar grains, especially 

of plagioclase, show undulose extinction, mechanical twinning and recrystallized grains. Quartz shows 

evidence of solid-state deformation, such as elongated grains, undulose extinction, deformation bands, 

recrystallized grains, ribbons and subgrains in chessboard pattern (Fig. 3.17b).  

The zone with Opx-bearing rocks show microstructures compatible with granulite facies 

metamorphic conditions. For instance, the occurrence of chessboard pattern in quartz and 

recrystallized plagioclase are indicative of metamorphic conditions varying from upper amphibolite to 

granulite facies (e.g., Kruhl 1996, Vernon 2000). However, the lack of prograde reactions and textural 

characteristics lead us to interpret that the main mineral assemblage, consisting of orthopyroxene, 

plagioclase and quartz, represent original igneous mineralogy (see also Gonçalves et al. 2014). Indeed, 

variable overprinting and retrograde reactions, such as hornblende rimming pyroxene and biotite 

replacing hornblende/pyroxene (Fig. 3.17a), indicate that these rocks were metamorphosed under 

amphibolite facies conditions. The retrograde event took place during the collisional phase of the 

Araçuaí orogen, which led to fluid migration and retrograde metamorphic reactions. 

 

Enclave-rich Tonalite-Granodiorite  

The enclave-rich Tonalite-Granodiorite association occurs in the northern, northeastern and 

eastern sectors of the study area (Fig. 3.15), where it is represented by the Galiléia and São Vítor 

plutons, mapped by Barbosa et al. (1964) and Féboli (1997), respectively. Tonalites, granodiorites and 

minor granites characterize the association. The contact with the adjacent units is marked by the 

presence of poorly exposed schists and gneiss, locally intruded by leucocratic veins (see also Mondou 

et al. 2012). The contact with the Rio Doce Group schists in the northern and southern sectors of the 

study area is made by thrust and dextral strike-slip shear zones (Tuller 2000) (Figs. 3.15 and 3.16). 

The dominant granodiorites are light to dark gray, medium- to coarse-grained (Fig. 3.17c), and 

consist of plagioclase (An27-50) (~40%), quartz (~35%), biotite (~12%), hornblende (~3%), orthoclase 

(~5%) and microcline (~5%). Garnet, titanite, allanite, epidote, apatite, rutile, ilmenite, magnetite, 

pyrrhotite and chalcopyrite are common accessory minerals. Muscovite and clinozoisite are secondary

euhedral plagioclase grain with concentric zoning, possibly with calcium-rich core (sample 5). e-h) Centimetric- 

to metric-scale enclaves hosted in a granodiorite within the enclave-rich lithofacies (sample 49); e-f) Enclaves 

showing rounded shapes; 

 

products of plagioclase breakdown, whilst chlorite forms as replacement of biotite (see also Nalini Jr. 

et al. 2005). 



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 84 

Petrographically, the tonalites from this association show almost the same mineralogical 

assemblage of the previously described granodiorites. The granites, on the other hand, show a lower 

content of mafic mineral, such as hornblende and biotite (see also Nalini Jr. 1997, and Nalini Jr. et al. 

2005 for more details). 

A large volume of melanocratic enclaves, whose composition varies from tonalitic/dioritic to 

gabbroic, is present mainly in the Galiléia pluton (Figs. 3.17e-h) (Nalini Jr. 1997, Nalini Jr. et al. 

2005, Gonçalves 2009, Mondou et al. 2012, Gonçalves et al. 2014). The enclaves show rounded 

shapes or are strongly elongated and flattened parallel to the regional foliation (Figs. 3.17e-h). They 

locally exhibit chilled margins (Fig. 3.17g), range from centimetric to metric-sized (Fig. 3.17e), and 

consist of hornblende, biotite, zoned plagioclase (An35-88), garnet and quartz, with apatite (locally 

acicular), zircon, titanite as main accessory minerals. 

The foliation, when affecting these rocks, is defined by the alignment of brown-reddish biotite 

(Fig. 3.17c), and sometimes associated with hornblende. Mylonites (along shear zones) and late 

leucocratic veins are locally observed. Quartz shows elongated grains, undulose extinction, subgrains 

or recrystallized grains as well as triple grain junctions, being the latter microstructural feature likely 

due to annealing process (Spry 1983, Evans et al. 2001). Feldspars show mechanical twinning, and 

undulose extinction. Plagioclase grains with concentric zoning, possibly hosting calcium-rich cores 

(e.g., Nalini Jr. 1997) are often observed (Fig. 3.17d). 

In the absence of critical mineral paragenesis, we used the common occurrence of biotite 

replacing hornblende, and microstructures of quartz and feldspars to suggest that the granodiorites of 

this association were deformed and recrystallized under amphibolite facies conditions. 

 

Enclave-poor Granite to Tonalite  

The enclave-poor Granite to Tonalite association, represented by Cuieté Velho and Alto 

Capim plutons mapped respectively by Barbosa et al. (1964) and Vieira (1993), is exposed in the 

central and the southeastern portions of the focused area (Fig. 3.15). The contacts with the surrounding 

rock units are marked by shear zones (Figs. 3.15 and 3.16). Granites, granodiorites, tonalites, and 

subordinate migmatites with rare mafic enclaves are the lithotypes of the association. 

The granites are light gray or nearly white, medium- to coarse-grained, and slightly foliated 

(Fig. 3.17i). The biotite is green-yellowish or light greenwish, occasionally product of hornblende 

breakdown. The hornblende is green-bluish (probably a tschermakitic variety) (Fig. 3.17j) (Hawthorne 

& Grundy 1973, Leake 1978, Fleet & Barbet 1978, Leake et al. 1997, Hawthorne & Oberti 2006). 

These rocks consist of quartz (~45%), plagioclase (up to 25%), K-feldspar (orthoclase and microcline, 

up to 20%), biotite (~7%), and hornblende (~3%). Zircon, allanite, titanite, and scarce garnet are

Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 86 

Petrographically, the granodiorites and tonalites from this association are quite similar. These 

rocks are light gray, mostly medium- to coarse-grained, with isotropic domains predominating over 

foliated regions. The occurrence of centimetric mafic enclaves is restricted to few outcrops. The biotite 

is mainly greenwish, and have pleocroic halos given by the occurrence of zircon grains. These rocks 

consist of plagioclase (showing mainly euhedral shapes), quartz, biotite, hornblende, and K-feldspar 

(microcline and minor orthoclase). Zircon, epidote, apatite, titanite, and scarce garnet are common 

accessory minerals. Clinozoisite is a secondary product of plagioclase breakdown.    

The foliation is marked mainly by the alignment of biotite. Quartz shows undulose extinction, 

subgrains or minor recrystallized grains. Feldspars are mostly anhedral, sometimes showing 

polygonal, straight and long boundaries, indicative of annealing process (Spry 1983, Evans et al. 

2001). The microcline exhibits recrystallized grains with common myrmekitic border, at the contact 

with plagioclase. Evidence of solid-state deformation in quartz associated with straight and long 

boundaries in feldspar grains what usually indicate prolonged period under temperature, without 

applied stress, characterizing annealing process, are the more pronounced microstructural features for 

this lithofacies.  

Besides the microstructures exhibited by quartz and feldspar aggregates, the presence of 

tschermakitic hornblende in the rocks of this association suggests metamorphic conditions ranging 

from medium- to upper-amphibolite grade. Nicholls et al. (1991), studying the region in the vicinity of 

Three Valley Gap, British Columbia, suggested metamorphic conditions of 8 Kbar and 700 ºC for 

boudins with assemblages dominated by amphibole (tschermakite, tschermakitic hornblende and 

magnesium-hornblende). 

 

Metavolcanic rocks of the Rio Doce Group 

Vieira (2007) described, for the first time, the occurrence of metavolcanic rocks within the Rio 

Doce Group (Fig. 3.15). Calc-alkaline dacitic to rhyolitic volcanoclastic rocks, exposed in the central-

eastern portion of the study area, occur intercalated with pelitic schists to gneisses and metawackes to 

quartz sandstones of the Palmital do Sul and Tumiritinga formations. These rocks underwent regional 

metamorphism in the greenschist-amphibolite facies transition to the sillimanite zone of the 

amphibolite facies (Vieira 2007, Gonçalves 2009, Gonçalves et al. 2010, 2014, Novo 2013). 

 The dacitic rocks are dark gray and preserve the original compositional layering. They consist 

of quartz, plagioclase, biotite and K-feldspar. Quartz and feldspar aggregates are embedded in a fine 

grained and slightly foliated matrix made up of quartz, feldspar and white mica. Zircon, titanite, 

allanite, opaques and scarce garnet are common accessory minerals. Muscovite, epidote and chlorite 

are secondary minerals derived from plagioclase and biotite breakdown. Clasts composed of single 

crystal of feldspar and/or polycrystalline quartz aggregate show rectangular, triangular or ovoid 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 87 

shapes, with sharp or curvilinear boundaries (Vieira 2007, Novo 2013). The clasts show thermal 

interaction with the matrix, indicative of fast cooling during magma flow. The plagioclase (most 

oligoclase) clasts are zoned, commonly show Albite or Carlsbad twinning, and display sharp and/or 

broken boundaries. The aforementioned textural features characterize these rocks as metamorphosed 

dacitic tuffs, in which the ash fraction (<2 cm) predominates over lapilli fraction (2 – 6.5 cm). In the 

slightly foliated dacitic rocks, the foliation is marked by the alignment of reddish biotite, and fine 

elongated quartz grains.  

The rhyolitic rocks were found only in an outcrop in the southeastern portion of the study area 

(Gonçalves 2009, Gonçalves et al. 2010) (sample L027 in Fig. 3.15). They are light gray (Fig. 3.17k), 

and composed of quartz, plagioclase, biotite and K-feldspar. Zircon, titanite, allanite, ilmenite and 

scarce garnet are common accessory minerals. Muscovite, epidote and chlorite derived from 

plagioclase and biotite breakdown form the secondary mineral assemblage. The rhyolitic rock is 

slightly foliated marked by the alignment of reddish biotite, and subordinated muscovite (Fig. 3.17k). 

The feldspar and quartz clasts, with rectangular or rounded external shapes are immersed in a fine 

grained micaceous quartzo-feldspathic matrix (Fig. 3.17l). The transition between the clasts and the 

matrix is abrupt, with sharp boundaries for the clasts, indicative of rapid cooling during magma flow 

(Fig. 3.17l). Quartz shows evidence of solid-state deformation, such as undulose extinction, and triple 

junctions indicating cooling with no applied stress. 

 

 Structure and spatial distribution of the plutonic and volcanic rocks   

Except for the Ibituruna syenite, a late orogenic intrusion, the units exposed in the studied area 

record three phases of deformation: D1, D2 and D3. 

The first phase generated ductile to ductile-brittle structures in response to an E-W 

compressional stress field. The D1 fabric elements include W-verging thrusts, folds, shear zones of 

various scales, and the regional S1 foliation in association with the L1 stretching lineation (Figs. 3.15 

and 3.16). Marked by the orientation of biotite and flattened quartz-feldspar aggregates, the S1 

foliation strikes preferentially NS and show moderate to steep dips to the east. The associated L1 

plunges ENE and the associated kinematic indicators attest an overall top to WSW motion (Fig. 3.16). 

The Abre Campo shear zone is the most prominent structure of the D1 phase. Marked in the 

field by an up to 1 km-thick mylonite zone, the E-dipping Abre Campo thrust juxtaposes two distinct 

basement complexes and associated cover units. The Rhyacian complexes intruded by the G1 

Supersuite granites on the east are thrust on top of the Archean basement overlain by the Tonian-

Ediacaran schists on the west. Other D1 thrusts associated with W-verging isoclinal to complex F1 

folds affect the hanging wall block of the Abre Campo shear zone, thereby dismembering and 

duplicating the magmatic succession of the G1 Supersuite (Figs. 3.15, 3.16 and 3.18). 



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 88 

During the second phase of deformation, NE-SW oriented compressional stresses led to 

nucleation of NS-trending dextral strike-slip shear zones and reactivation of the preexistent tectonic 

elements. The D2-structures are more common in the eastern half of the study area, as shown in the 

map of Fig. 3.15. 

NE-trending normal shear zones associated to SE-verging folds and a crenulation cleavage are 

the main structures of the D3-phase. The normal shear zones very often reactivate D1 and D2 structures 

and are especially well developed in the schists of the Rio Doce Group. 

The contact relationships between the basement and younger rocks in the hanging wall of the 

Abre Campo shear zone strongly suggest that the block of the Rhyacian Pocrane Complex represents a 

preexistent basement high. Plunging north and apparently tilted to the east, this block is thrust on top 

of the zone with Opx-bearing rocks of the G1 Supersuite that lie on the west. Along its eastern edge, 

the basement block is intruded by various plutons of the Cuieté Velho and Galiléia bodies, cut by 

dextral strike slip shear zones and partially covered by the rocks of the Palmital do Sul Formation of 

the Rio Doce Group. 

Although dismembered by thrusts and strike-slip shear zones and significantly affected by 

erosion processes, the magmatic succession of the G1 Supersuite is well preserved in the northern 

segment of the studied area. Along the AA’ cross-section (Figs. 3.15 and 3.16), the zone with Opx-

bearing rocks at the base of the succession passes to the enclave-rich Tonalite-Granodiorite 

association, which is in turn covered by the metavolcano-sedimentary rocks of the Rio Doce Group. 

This whole package dips east and is thrust to the west on the top of the Rhyacian basement rocks, 

meaning that the basal portion of the section, marked by the zone with Opx-bearing rocks, once lie at 

least at the same level of the granulite-facies rocks of the Juiz de Fora Complex. The cross-cut 

relationships between the G1 lithofacies associations observed in the field and reproduced in the 

geological map of figure 3.15 and cross sections of figure 3.16 suggest that enclave-rich and enclave-

poor units were apparently emplaced at the same crustal level (Fig. 3.18). Despite the intervening 

basement high represented by the Pocrane Complex, the magmatic sequence exposed in the 

northernmost part of the study area is thus made up of a zone with Opx-bearing rocks, such as norites, 

diorites, and minor lenses of gabbros and tonalites at the base, tonalites to granites with or without the 

occurrence of mafic enclaves in the intermediate level, and a cover of silicic volcanic (i.e., dacites and 

rhyolites) and sedimentary rocks. The metasedimentary rocks are locally intruded by granites and 

tonalites bodies from the intermediate level (Fig. 3.18). The local absence of the intensively shearing 

along strike-slip shear zones and the fact that both the Abre Campo shear zone and the thrust beneath 

the zone with Opx-bearing rocks dip east, being followed in this orientation by the regional foliation 

and lithological contacts, strongly suggest that the mentioned succession samples a piece of crust 

made up of magmatic rocks emplaced in relatively deeper to more shallower levels, i.e., a tilted 

magmatic crustal section.

Analytical procedures 

Zircon U-Pb analyses were performed at the Universidade de São Paulo (USP) (samples 

L100A and L100B) and at the Geochronology Laboratory - Geosciences Institute at the Universidade 

Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS) (other samples). The results are shown on Tables 3.4 and 3.5 

and Fig. 3.19. 

Zircons were hand-picked and mounted on adhesive tape, enclosed in epoxy resin and then 

polished and photographed in transmitted light. Extensive use of cathodoluminescence (CL) and 

backscattered electron (BSE) imaging was made in order to identify internal structures and choose 

potential target sites for U-Pb analyses. The mounts were then cleaned and the U-Pb isotopic 

compositions of zircons were analyzed by using the Eximer Laser (ArF - 193 nm beam current) (USP) 



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 90 

and the New Wave UP213 (UFRGS) Laser Ablation Microprobe coupled to a Multi Collector – 

Inductively Coupled Plasma – Mass Spectrometry (LA-MC-ICP-MS) by NEPTUNE (Thermo 

Scientific) company. Spot laser ablation was adopted in this study with a beam size of 25 ?m and laser 

pulse frequency of 8Hz (USP) and 10 Hz (UFRGS). Laser-induced elemental fractional and 

instrumental mass discrimination were corrected using the reference zircon (GJ-1) (Jackson et al. 

2004). Two GJ-1 analyses were measured after ten spots in unknown sample. The external error was 

calculated after the propagation error of the GJ-1 mean and the individual sample zircon (or spot). For 

more details on the LA-MC-ICP-MS method, corrections and running conditions used in this study, 

see Chemale Jr. et al. (2012). 

The whole-rock Sm-Nd isotopic analysis was carried out on four samples from the G1 

Supersuite at the Geochronology Laboratory - Geosciences Institute at the Universidade Federal de 

Brasilia, following the method described by Gioia & Pimentel (2000). The analyzed samples were 

granodiorites (samples L001, L003 and L005) and one monzogranite (sample L188) of the enclave-

rich and the enclave-poor lithofacies associations, respectively. The results are shown on Table 3.6 and 

Fig. 3.22.

Sample L100A is a gray fine- to medium-grained diorite (Fig. 3.20a) that contains plagioclase, 

hornblende, biotite, and minor quartz and orthopyroxene. The accessory assemblage is composed of 

apatite, zircon, ilmenite and magnetite. The foliation of this sample is marked by the alignment of 

subhedral to anhedral biotite and hornblende.  

Zircon grains extracted from this sample consist of long-prismatic or rounded boundary grains. 

They have mean length/width ratio of 4:1, although higher values up to 5:1 were obtained. The longer 

axis does not overcome 200 ?m, whilst the shorter axis is in average equals to 30 ?m. They have high 

Th/U ratios (0.26-0.53) with a single exception (Th/U = 0.14) (Table 3.5). Most grains are medium- 

gray and some display magmatic oscillatory zoning on CL images (Fig. 3.21). Attempts to obtain ages 

from the cores were unsuccessful due to the high level of discordance, however apparent ages of 

approximately 800 Ma and 1900 Ma are suggestive of inherited ages. No metamorphic overgrowth 

was observed, although rounded boundary is a common feature. Six concordant to near-concordant 

spot analyses yielded an age of 581 ± 11 Ma (MSWD = 0.063) (Fig. 3.19a). This age is interpreted as 

the best approximation of the crystallization age for this sample.   

Sample L100B was collected in a leucocratic vein that cuts the previously described diorite in 

the same outcrop of sample L100A. The light-gray, medium- to coarse-grained syenogranite (Fig. 

3.20a) consists of microcline, quartz, plagioclase and biotite. The accessory assemblage is made up of 

garnet, rutile and zircon. The predominant secondary mineral is muscovite formed due to plagioclase 

breakdown. The rock fabric is isotropic with subhedral to anhedral biotite forming isolated aggregates. 

The garnet crystals are partially replaced by biotite and/or chlorite.  

Zircons of this sample comprise short-prismatic, elongate or even rounded boundary grains. 

They have length/width ratios predominantly of 2:1, although higher values up to 4:1 were obtained. 

The longer axis does not overcome 300 ?m, whilst the shorter axis is in average equals to 70 ?m. They 

have mostly high Th/U ratios (?0.36) (Table 3.5), most grains are dark-gray and some of them display 

magmatic oscillatory zoning on CL images (Fig. 3.21). Five concordant spot analyses in five zircon 

grains yielded a concordia age of 556 ± 10 Ma (MSWD = 0.039) (Fig. 3.19b). We interpreted this age 

as the crystallization age of this sample. Eight spot analyses of cores yielded apparent ages between 

600 Ma and 1000 Ma and are interpreted as inherited zircon grains.

Zircon grains extracted from this sample are large (up to 400 µm) elongated with length/width

Sample L003 was collected from an abandoned quarry (UTM 239888/7880586) in 

northeastern portion of the studied area, near the town of Conselheiro Pena (Fig. 3.15). The outcrop 

consists of a granodiorite with a large number of enclaves (Fig. 3.20c). The host granodiorite consists

apatite (locally acicular), zircon, titanite as main accessory minerals (see also Nalini Jr. 1997 and

The zircon population of this sample comprises short-prismatic and elongate grains without 

inherited cores (Fig. 3.21). Their length/width ratio is in average of 3:1. Higher values up to 8:1 were 

also observed. The longest axis does not overcome 450 ?m, whilst the shorter axis is in average 85

possible to calculate a concordia age of 579 ± 8 Ma (MSWD = 0.21) (Fig. 3.19d). We interpret this 

age as the crystallization age of this sample. 

Sample L005 was collected in a natural outcrop (UTM 229892/7882280), located near the

accessory and secondary mineral assemblage is made up of garnet, titanite, zircon, rutile and epidote. 

Centimetric to metric-sized mafic enclaves with spherical to slightly elongated shapes occur in the 

outcrop (Fig. 3.20d).  

Similarly to the previous sample (L003), the zircon grains of this sample (L005) comprise 

short-prismatic and elongate grains with no inherited cores (Fig. 3.21). They have length/width ratios

 Enclave-poor Granite to Tonalite association (sample L188) 

Sample L188 was collected in a natural outcrop (UTM 247019/7816689), located in the 

southeastern sector of the study area, approximately 10 km north of the town of Mutum (Fig. 3.15). 

The sample corresponds to a light-gray medium- to coarse-grained monzogranite (Fig. 3.20e) and 

consists of quartz, plagioclase and biotite. Accessory and secondary mineral assemblage are made up 

of garnet, titanite, zircon and allanite. An isotropic fabric predominates in the outcrop. A deformed 

portion show a foliation marked preferentially by the orientation of biotite crystals (Fig. 3.20e).  

Zircon population of this sample consists of 2:1 and 4:1 prismatic grains showing oscillatory 

zoning (Fig. 3.21) and high Th/U ratios (0.25-0.65) (Table 3.5). Zircon analyses that are highly 

discordant or present high isotopic ratio errors were not included in age calculation. For six spot 

analyses a concordia age at 593 ± 10 Ma (MSWD = 0.064) was obtained for this sample (Fig. 3.19f). 

This age is interpreted as the best approximation of the crystallization age of this sample.  

 

Metavolcanoclastic rock of the Rio Doce Group (sample L027) 

Sample L027 was collected in a natural outcrop (UTM 250860/7838355), located near the 

Manhuaçu river, approximately 20 km south of the village of Santa Rita do Itueto (Fig. 3.15). The 

sample is a light-gray fine- to coarse-grained meta-rhyolite, with regions of a homogeneous fabric, 

free of a pervasive foliation, alternating with strongly deformed portions (Figs. 3.17k, and 3.20f). The 

meta-rhyolite consists of quartz, orthoclase, microcline, biotite and minor muscovite. Accessory 

mineral assemblage and secondary minerals is made up of zircon, ilmenite, chlorite, carbonate and 

epidote. Quartz and feldspar grains form ovoid aggregates (Fig. 3.17l).  

The zircon population of this sample comprises short-prismatic and elongate grains (Fig. 

3.21). They have length/width ratios predominantly of 2:1, although higher values up to 3:1 were 

obtained. The longer axis does not overcome 250 ?m, whilst the shorter axis is in average equals to 70 

?m. Eight spot analyses were obtained for the same number of zircon grains. Two very discordant 

grains with older 
207

Pb/
206

Pb ages are possible xenocrysts. The remaining six zircon grains have 

oscillatory zoning (Fig. 3.21) and high Th/U ratios (0.29-0.89) (Table 3.5). A concordia age calculated

for three near concordant spot analyses yielded an age of 578 ± 7 Ma (MSWD = 0.00085) (Fig. 3.19g).
