Results of the Sm-Nd method 

Neodymium (Nd) isotope results are shown on Table 3.6 and Fig. 3.22. Sample L001 

(enclave-rich Tonalite-Granodiorite association) has ?Nd(t) = -6.6, TDM model age = 1.51 Ga, while 

samples L003 and L005 (also from the enclave-rich unit) yielded ?Nd(t) = -13.07 and -6.52, and TDM 

model ages = 1.87 and 1.56 Ga, respectively. Sample L188 (enclave-poor lithofacies unit) yielded 

?Nd(t) = -8.21 and TDM model age = 1.59 Ga. These data were calculated for the mean age of the G1 

granitoids, which is assumed to fall around 600 Ma (Table 3.6). 

 

SUMMARY AND INTERPRETATION 

 The magmatic rock assemblage of the G1 Supersuite and Rio Doce Group we investigated in 

the central portion of the Araçuaí orogen comprises three distinct associations of plutonic rocks and a 

metamorphosed volcanosedimentary succession, which includes dacitic and rhyolitic tuffs (Figs. 3.15, 

3.17, 3.18, and 3.20).  

Chemically, the G1 Supersuite rocks consist mostly of magnesian, metaluminous to slightly 

peraluminous, calc-alkaline to alkali-calcic and medium- to high-K acidic rocks. The dacitic and 

rhyolitic rocks of the Rio Doce Group on the other hand are mainly magnesian, peraluminous, calcic 

to calc-alkaline and medium- to high-K acidic rocks.  

According to our new zircon U-Pb data, the ages of the granitic plutonic rocks vary between 

ca. 625 Ma and 579 Ma (Fig. 3.19 and Tables 3.4 and 3.5), while the age we obtained for the rhyolitic 

volcanoclastic rock of the Rio Doce Group is ca. 578 Ma. Thus, within errors, the studied plutonic and 

volcanic rocks might belong to the same magmatic event. This event, predating (with some overlap) 

the ages of emplacement of syn-collisional, S-type granites (G2 Supersuite) between 590 Ma to 545 

Ma, peaking at 575 Ma, might represent the subduction-related, pre-collisional, event that took place 

in the Araçuaí orogen between 630 and 580 Ma (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2001, 2011, Silva et al. 2011, 

Gonçalves et al. 2014, 2015, Gradim et al. 2014, Peixoto et al. 2015, Tedeschi et al. 2015). However, 

the leucocratic vein (sample L100B) intrusive in the Opx-bearing rock (sample L100A) (Fig. 3.20a) 

yielded a crystallization age of ca. 556 Ma, recording thus the syn-collisional magmatism as 

documented especially in the back-arc domain of the orogen (see Gradim et al. 2014 and references 

therein).

DISCUSSION  

The studied magmatic section in the geologic scenario of the Araçuaí orogen 

Rocks of the G1 Supersuite exposed in other areas of the Araçuaí orogen vary from gabbros to 

monzogranites with tonalites and granodiorites representing by far the most common lithotypes. The 

vast majority of the G1 rocks is metaluminous to slightly peraluminous (Fig. 3.23a), and show great 

similarity to members of calc-alkaline series (Fig. 3.23b) (Gonçalves et al. 2014, Tedeschi et al. 

2015). The diagram of Figure 3.23a show that the higher values of Aluminum Saturation Index (ASI) 

are related to the lower maficity (Fe + Mg) numbers for the G1 rocks, characterizing thus a typical I-

type granite trend (e.g., Clemens et al. 2011).  



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 101 

In primitive mantle-normalized incompatible element spidergrams, the G1 rock assemblage 

display overall Large Ion Lithophile Elements (LILE)-enriched patterns (Rb, Ba, Th, K), with values 

between 100 and 500 times higher than the primitive mantle values (Sun & McDonough 1989), 

suggesting important crustal sourcing (Fig. 3.23c) (e.g., Gonçalves et al. 2015). Significant negative 

Nb-Ta, Sr and Ti anomalies were observed in the G1 rocks (Fig. 3.23c). The negative Nb-Ta, and Ti 

anomalies could be due to the presence of rutile at the site of melting (e.g., McCulloch & Gamble 

1991). On the other hand, the negative Sr and Ti anomalies could result respectively from the 

segregation of feldspar during fractional crystallization and in part of Fe oxides (Arndt 2013), while a 

low ratio of Nb to Ta have been ascribed to the signature of amphibole fractionation (Foley et al. 

2002). These geochemical signatures could also been inherited from the source of the G1 granitic 

magmas. Using the discrimination diagram based on the concentrations of Y, Nb and Rb (Pearce et al. 

1984), the G1 rock compositions plot both in the volcanic arc and intraplate fields (Fig. 3.23d).  

The pre-collisional, volcanic arc signature (Fig. 3.23d) of the G1 rocks, combined with other 

lithochemical and isotopic data, led several authors to interpret this supersuite as a magmatic arc 

formed on an active continental margin setting, developed from ca. 630 Ma to 580 Ma (Figueiredo & 

Campos-Neto 1993, Nalini Jr. 1997, Pedrosa-Soares & Wiedemann-Leonardos 2000, Pedrosa-Soares 

et al. 2001, 2011, Martins et al. 2004, Gonçalves et al. 2010, 2014, 2015, Novo et al. 2010, Tedeschi 

et al. 2015).    

The G1 Supersuite includes suites, batholiths and stocks with many local names, such as 

Brasilândia, Derribadinha, Divino, Galiléia, São Vitor, Estrela-Muniz Freire, Manhuaçu, Muriaé, 

Guarataia, Teófilo Otoni and others. They in general consist of a great diversity of lithotypes. Opx-

bearing rocks predominate in the Chaves, Derribadinha, Divino, Serra do Valentim and Marceleza 

plutonic units (Féboli 1997, Pinto et al. 2000, Novo et al. 2010, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Tedeschi 

2013, Gonçalves et al. 2014, Tedeschi et al. 2015). Enclave-rich Tonalite-Granodiorite assemblages 

predominates in the Baixo Guandu, Brasilândia, Estrela-Muniz Freire, Galiléia, Manhuaçu, Muriaé, 

São Vítor and Serra da Bolívia plutonic units, and in most plutons of the northern tip of the Rio Doce 

arc (Barbosa et al. 1964, 1966, Pinto et al. 2000, Martins et al. 2004, Gonçalves et al. 2010, 2014, 

2015, Novo 2013, Tedeschi 2013, Tedeschi et al. 2015). Some isolated intrusions, like the Guarataia 

and Teófilo Otoni plutons (Martins et al. 2004, Tedeschi 2013, Tedeschi et al. 2015), and a plutonic 

assemblage found in the study area intrusions are ascribed to the enclave-poor Granite to Tonalite 

associations (Fig. 3.15). Petrographically and chemically no clear differences exists between the 

lithofacies associations discriminated in this study and the G1 rock associations described by other 

authors and synthesized in Pedrosa-Soares et al. (2011), Gonçalves et al. (2014) and Tedeschi et al. 

(2015).

The ages obtained here combined with published data show that the crystallization of the Opx-

bearing unit (represented by sample L100A) occurred mainly between ca. 600 and 580 Ma (Table 3.4) 

(see Novo 2009, Tedeschi 2013, Gonçalves et al. 2014). Specific for the Derribadinha Tonalite, three 

age determinations are available. Petitgirard et al. (2009) dated the Derribadinha Tonalite exposed in 

the town of Governador Valadares (Fig. 3.15), obtaining the crystallization age of 580 ± 8 Ma (U-Pb, 

LA-ICP-MS). A foliated tonalite exposed near the town of Inhapim, dated by Gonçalves et al. (2014), 

yielded a crystallization age of 597 ± 4 Ma (U-Pb, LA-ICP-MS). Zircon overgrowths from a biotite 

gneiss of Derribadinha pluton have yielded the U-Pb SHRIMP age of 561 ± 8 Ma, interpreted as 

product of the main metamorphic event affecting the unit (Silva et al. 2011). The age of 556 ± 10 Ma 

of the leucocratic vein (sample L100B - Fig. 3.19b) obtained here may also be associated to the syn-



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 103 

collisional event that affected the Araçuaí Orogen (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2001, 2008, Alkmim et al. 

2006, Gradim et al. 2014).  

The available geochronological data combined with ages obtained in our study indicate that 

the crystallization of the enclave-rich lithofacies granitoids occurred between 625 and 579 Ma (Table 

3.4). Nalini Jr. (1997) obtained a crystallization age of 594 ± 6 Ma (U-Pb, TIMS zircon) for a 

granodiorite, close to the town of Conselheiro Pena, while Pedrosa-Soares et al. (2011) obtained a 

crystallization age of 597 ± 3 Ma (U-Pb, LA-ICP-MS) in a foliated biotite-hornblende tonalite with 

associated mafic enclaves belonging to the Manhuaçu stock, near the homonymous town (Table 3.4). 

More recently, Gonçalves et al. (2014) obtained a crystallization age of 581 ± 3 Ma (U-Pb, LA-ICP-

MS) for a foliated quartz diorite enclave occurring in the Galiléia Suite, also a component of this unit.  

For the enclave-poor lithofacies association, Paes (1999) obtained a crystallization age of 625 

± 11 Ma (Pb/Pb evaporation zircon) in a foliated tonalite, near the town of Alvarenga, while Tedeschi 

(2013) obtained an age of 576 ± 9 Ma (U/Pb SHRIMP) in a granodiorite within the Guarataia pluton, 

near the town of Itambacuri. Both ages are significantly different from the age of 593 ± 10 Ma (sample 

L188 - Fig. 3.19f) obtained in our study (Table 3.4). Due to the poor accuracy of the technique used by 

Paes (1999), we suggest that the principal magmatic episode responsible for the crystallization of 

granitic rocks from this unit occurred between 593 and 576 Ma.  

The ages we have determined (578 ± 7 Ma) for the volcanosedimentary counterpart of the G1 

Supersuite, the Rio Doce Group, are in agreement with data provided for dacitic rocks of the 

Tumiritinga (585 ± 4 Ma) and Palmital do Sul (584 ± 5 Ma) formations by Vieira (2007).   

Sr and Nd isotopic composition data from this study combined with published data show that 

the majority of the granitic rocks that compose the G1 Supersuite have TDM ages between 1.39 and 

2.26 Ga, high initial 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios, from 0.7088 to 0.7233 (see Martins et al. 2004), and negative 

?Nd(t) values, calculated for the time of emplacement (ca. 600 Ma), from -6.52 to -13.83 (Table 3.6). 

Recent zircon Lu-Hf isotope data revealed for the G1 rocks ?Hf(t) values mainly between -5.2 and -

11.7, with TDM ages of ca. 1.5-2.0 Ga (see Gonçalves et al. 2015, Tedeschi et al. 2015). These isotopic 

data suggest contribution and/or partial melting of an old Meso- to Paleo-proterozoic continental crust 

to the G1 magmatism (see also Nalini Jr. et al. 2005, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 

2014, 2015, Tedeschi et al. 2015). In addition, the inherited zircon ages match the ages of the 

surrounding basement rocks (Juiz de Fora and Pocrane complexes) (Machado et al. 1996, Noce et al. 

2007, Heilbron et al. 2010, Novo 2013, Gonçalves et al. 2014).  

In sum, the results we obtained are in agreement with the literature data on the G1 Supersuite 

exposed in the remaining sectors of the Araçuaí orogen. They basically reinforce the interpretation that 

the G1 Supersuite members were emplaced and incorporate significant amounts of a Rhyacian-



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 104 

Calymmian continental crust between 630 and 580 Ma (e.g., Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et 

al. 2014, 2015).  

An import aspect of our study steams from the fact that each individual lithofacies forming the 

investigated section cannot be discriminated in terms of their crystallization ages. In other words, from 

the base up to the top, the magmatic section seems to reflect a cumulative emplacement process by 

multiple magmatic pulses in the time interval of 630 Ma to 580 Ma. 

 

The studied section as representative of a continental magmatic arc 

The G1 Supersuite components exhibit petrographic, geochemical and isotopic attributes (e.g., 

Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014, 2015, and references therein) similar to other 

ancient and modern magmatic arcs developed along continental margins (e.g., Kistler et al. 1986, 

Dunphy & Ludden 1998, Pankhurst et al. 1998, Frost et al. 2001, DeCelles et al. 2009, Ducea et al. 

2015a,b). With a typical calc-alkaline trend and compositionally similar to other Cordilleran-type 

granitoids worldwide (e.g., Pearce et al. 1984, Frost et al. 2001, Winter 2001, Frost & Frost et al. 

2008), the G1 Supersuite show Nd and Sr isotopic signatures, high initial 
87

Sr/
86

Sr values, low initial 

143
Nd/

144
Nd ratios, which together point toward an isotopically enriched source, such as the continental 

crust.  

In a recent review, Ducea et al. (2015a) presented an idealized succession for the components 

of continental magmatic arcs, noting that some tilted crustal sections along the Americas Pacific 

margin expose the arcs deepest portions. From the base to the top, the ca. 40 km-thick succession 

consists of garnet granulite residues/cumulates, spinel peridotites, garnet clinopyroxenite lenses, 

noritic to pyroxene diorite-tonalite intrusives, diorite-tonalite intrusives into metasedimentary and 

metavolcanic rocks, granites and tonalites, mafic dikes, and silicic volcanics. With some differences 

from the idealized section, such as the occurrence of a larger package of metasedimentary rocks at the 

top and absence of mafic dikes, the Ordovician Famatinian arc sequence (Argentina) (Tibaldi et al. 

2013) is indicated by Ducea et al. (2015b) as a typical and almost complete continental magmatic arc 

succession.  

 The lithofacies associations we discriminated and their succession along the investigated 

section approach, with some differences, the idealized continental magmatic arc crust described by 

Ducea et al. (2015a). The differences stand for the fact that residues/cumulates, garnet-bearing rocks, 

peridotites and mafic dikes have not been recognized in the G1 associations yet.  

Magmatic rock successions similar to the section we described here have been identified in 

crustal sections exposed in different parts of the world. The Sierra de Valle Vértil, central Argentina, is 

a well-exposed section through the middle to lower crust, documenting the nature of mafic magmatism 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 105 

and its differentiation to higher silica contents at 15–25 km depths (Otamendi et al. 2012). Other 

examples of well-studied rocks from deep crustal levels include Fiordland in New Zealand, and 

southern Sierra Nevada and Salinia, in the western coast of USA (e.g., Kidder et al. 2003, De Paoli et 

al. 2009, Ducea et al. 2015a,b), exposing up to ~ 50 Km of continental crust. Invariably, these deep 

crustal cross sections are characterized by a dominant mafic material, and also comprise intermediate 

rocks with or without the occurrence of orthopyroxene, such as norite, diorite and tonalite (see cross 

section of Fig. 5 from Ducea et al. 2015a). As the studied Opx-bearing unit is composed of similar 

lithotypes, show high temperature mineral assemblages (i.e., orthopyroxene occurrence) and 

microstructures (chessboard subgrains in quartz), we suggest that the Opx-bearing lithofacies 

association represent the exposition of a crust at least 30 Km-thick (Fig. 3.18). 

A good example of lower (~ 35 km) to upper (~ 5 km) crust exposure is given by the Sierra 

Nevada Batholith (Chapman et al. 2012, and references therein). Mostly composed of tonalites and 

granodiorites, this batholith also encompasses mafic enclaves, attesting to the presence of mafic 

magmatism in their heat and mass budgets, although true gabbroic intrusive are subordinate (e.g., 

Ducea et al. 2015a). The granitic rocks forming the enclave-rich Tonalite-Granodiorite and enclave-

poor Granite to Tonalite lithofacies associations have their emplacement levels constrained either by 

igneous barometric techniques (e.g., Al in hornblende) or pressure determinations on mineralogical 

metamorphic assemblages. Bilal et al. (2000), based on Al content in hornblende, estimated pressures 

between 8 and 10 Kbar for the emplacement of granites from the Galiléia Suite, which belongs to the 

enclave-rich lithofacies. The temperature is roughly constrained from 750 to 850 ºC, based on zircon 

morphologies hosted in granites from the Galiléia Suite (Nalini Jr. 1997). The occurrence of 

tschermakitic hornblende within the enclave-poor rocks, in turn, suggests slightly lower pressure (~ 8 

Kbar) and temperature (~ 700 ºC) conditions for the emplacement of granites from this facies. 

Although, this approximation must be tested using more precise thermobarometric quantitative 

techniques, no clear clue exists distinguishing the emplacement levels for both enclave-rich and 

enclave-poor lithofacies. By comparison with other magmatic arcs, we propose that the rocks forming 

these lithofacies were emplaced at depths of approximately 20 to 25 km (Fig. 3.18).  

As previously mentioned, the G1 Supersuite rocks together with the volcanosedimentary 

sequence of the Rio Doce Group are portrayed as the Rio Doce magmatic arc (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 

2008, 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014 and references therein), precursor of the Araçuaí orogen. 

Comparing attributes of the Rio Doce arc as a whole with other Precambrian and Phanerozoic 

continental magmatic arcs allows us to discuss the processes involved in its development and 

evolution. The Rio Doce arc has a great petrological and isotopic similarity to the Paleoproterozoic 

magmatic arc exposed in the Ungava orogen, northern Quebec, Canada (Dunphy & Ludden 1998). 

The Narsajuaq terrane, a major component of the Ungava orogen, comprises many biotite ± 

hornblende ± pyroxene-bearing plutons, which were interpreted to be the plutonic roots of a magmatic 



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 106 

arc (Dunphy & Ludden 1998). Consisting of several deformed and undeformed plutons, the Narsajuaq 

terrane, is made up of diorites, monzodiorites, tonalites and granites, mostly with geochemical 

characteristics similar to a calc-alkaline series, and exhibiting metaluminous to slightly peraluminous 

signature. The Paleoproterozoic granitoids show moderate to high concentrations of large-ion 

lithophile elements (e.g. Rb, Ba, Th and K) and light rare earth elements, pronounced negative Nb-Ta 

and Ti anomalies, and fractioned REEs, comparable to modern arc granites (see also Gonçalves et al. 

2015). Dunphy & Ludden (1998) attributed these features predominantly as a primary result of the 

construction of the Paleoproterozoic magmatic arc upon a fragment of older continental crust. 

Although mineralogically and geochemically similar to the Rio Doce components, the plutonic rocks 

of the Narsajuaq terrane show small differences, when the Sr and Nd isotopic data is considered. The 

rocks forming the Paleoproterozoic arc have initial 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios and ?Nd(t) values, calculated for the 

time of emplacement (ca. 1863-1800 Ma), varying from 0.7020 to 0.7048, and from +4.0 to -10.7, 

respectively (Dunphy & Ludden 1998). These values suggest a minor contribution of juvenile material 

during its development, but differ from the Rio Doce arc, for the fact that ?Nd values close to zero or 

slightly positive have not been found for the granitic rocks of the Rio Doce arc yet. 

The Rio Doce arc is also similar to some Phanerozoic continental magmatic arcs. It has a great 

petrographic, geochemical and isotopic similarity to the granitoids of the Los Llanos-Ulapes batholith, 

except for pyroxene-bearing granitoids, which have not been reported in the latter. The Los Llanos-

Ulapes batholith, interpreted by Pankhurst et al. (1998) as the southern part of the Early- to Middle-

Ordovician Famatinian continental magmatic arc, is exposed in the central part of the Sierras 

Pampeanas, close to Chile-Argentina boundary (Pankhurst et al. 1998). The batholith consists 

predominantly of biotite ± hornblende granitoids, mostly metaluminous and with calc-alkaline 

signature. Composed of slightly to strongly foliated plutons, the most abundant rock-type of the 

batholith is granodiorite, with minor amounts of biotite monzodiorite, monzogranite, two micas and 

cordierite monzogranite, as well as several small bodies of hornblende-bearing gabbro-diorite and 

quartz diorite. These Famatinian rocks display both Nb-Ta and Sr negative anomalies, and a 

significant negative Ba anomaly, which might be associated to lesser involvement of crustal sourcing 

(see Grosse et al. 2011). With small differences in terms of the mineralogy and geochemistry, the 

plutonic rocks of this portion of the Famatinian arc, show Sr and Nd isotopic signatures similar to the 

Rio Doce magmatic arc. The Famatinian arc (ca. 490 Ma) has high initial 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios (between 

0.7075 and 0.7105) and low ?Nd(t) ranging from -4.6 to -6.3. According to Pankhurst et al. (1998) 

these values combined with Sm-Nd model ages of 1600-1700 Ma indicate that the Famatinian arc 

inherited crustal material.   

The Early- to Late-Cretaceous Sierra Nevada batholith (ca. 93-77 Ma), which includes the 

Sonora and Mono Creek plutons, as well as the Tuolumne Intrusive Suite (Bateman & Chappell 1979, 

Bateman 1992, Kistler et al. 1986), comprises a great variety of rock compositions. Made up of many 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 107 

distinct bodies, the main components of the batholith are hornblende gabbro, diorite, granodiorite, 

quartz monzonite and biotite granite (Kistler et al. 1986). With Sr and Nd isotopic signatures similar to 

the Rio Doce magmatic arc, the Sierra Nevada batholith have initial 
87

Sr/
86

Sr ratios varying from 

0.7056 to 0.7073, initial 
143

Nd/
144

Nd ratios between 0.51239 and 0.51211 and ?Nd(t) values between -3 

and -8 (Kistler et al. 1986, Gray et al. 2008). Some processes have been proposed, such as fractional 

crystallization, partial melting of compositionally variable source materials followed by fractional 

crystallization, and assimilation-fractional crystallization, to explain the compositional variation of the 

Sierra Nevada plutons, particularly for the Tuolumne Intrusive Suite (Frey et al. 1978, Bateman & 

Chappell 1979, Dogde et al. 1982, and references therein). Kistler et al. (1986), however, proposed 

that magma mixing might have been the more suitable process to explain the generation and evolution 

of the Tuolumne Intrusive Suite. Furthermore, variation of Sr isotopic compositions could not be due 

to solely fractionation of magma under closed-system conditions, and comparison of the chemical 

variations relative to the isotopic variations indicates that a variety of processes and more than one 

parent magmas would be required to account for its compositional zoning. 

The continental crustal section rarely preserves a window showing both the plutonic root and 

volcanic top of magmatic arcs (for exceptions see parts of the Laramide Cordilleran interior arcs, 

Arizona and Nevada) (Barton 1996). As highlighted by Paterson et al. (2011), the volcanic-to-plutonic 

ratio is highly variable but small, ranging from 1:2 to 1:20, suggesting that a great volume of magma 

freezes at depth, while only a small volume erupts. However, when present, the volcanic cover is 

dominated by dacites and andesites (see for example an Andean crustal segment in southern Peru) 

(Thouret et al. 2007). The Rio Doce Group rocks, as already postulated by Vieira (2007), Pedrosa-

Soares et al. (2011) and Gonçalves et al. (2010, 2014), accumulated as arc cover units (Fig. 3.18). 

Schists and gneisses within this Group record metamorphic conditions from lower to middle 

amphibolite facies, with temperature ranging from 638 ± 76 ºC at 4.56 ± 1 Kbar to 468 ± 50 ºC at 4.96 

± 1 Kbar (Vieira 2007). It is suggestive from our observations and data from the literature that the G1 

Supersuite lithofacies and the Rio Doce Group rocks preserve at least 30 km of continental crust (Fig. 

3.18). Therefore, according to our interpretation, the studied area exposes a tectonically dismembered 

continental magmatic arc section containing representatives from the plutonic roots (G1 Supersuite) up 

to the volcanic roof (Rio Doce Group) of the so-called Rio Doce magmatic arc (Fig. 3.18). A 

composed and idealized crustal section for the Rio Doce is shown on figure 3.24. This interpretation is 

in accordance with mineralogical, petrological features as well as crustal depths of other classical 

continental magmatic arcs, such as the previously mentioned Sierra de Valle Vértil, Salinian, and 

Sierra Nevada, formed in continental margin settings (see Otamendi et al. 2012, Ducea et al. 2015a,b 

for review). 

The close spatial relationship between the arc root rocks and gneisses of the Juiz de Fora 

Complex suggest an involvement of HT-melting of granulitic sources for the generation of part of the 



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central ....

arc root rocks and thus a deeper crustal level for the emplacement of it. On the other hand, the spatial 

relationship of the enclave-rich and enclave-poor lithofacies units with gneisses and schists, suggest a 

shallower crustal level emplacement for the granitoids of these units (Figs. 3.18, 3.24 and 3.25). This 

interpretation is quite similar to that proposed by Dunphy & Ludden (1998) for the plutonic rocks of 

the Paleoproterozoic magmatic arc of the Ungava orogen in Canada. 

 

Development of Rio Doce magmatic section 

The petrographic, geochemical and isotopic similarity between the G1 Supersuite section and 

the Paleoproterozoic magmatic arc of the Ungava orogen, as well as the Paleozoic Famatinian 

magmatic arc and the Mesozoic Tuolumne Intrusive suite, lead us to conclude that determining the 

first order igneous process, such as detailed calculations of partial melting, crystal fractionation, 

amount of material involved in mantle and crustal mixing, and the role played by assimilation-

fractional crystallization processes is not instructive at the present time. Although the overall pattern 

shown on several geochemical diagrams (e.g., Gonçalves et al. 2014, 2015 and references therein), 

and its general petrographic characteristics suggest that there is a genetic relationship among 

granitoids of the individualized units, favoring a common process of fractional crystallization of the 

major igneous phases, other igneous processes such as melting, assimilation, storage and 

homogenization (MASH) with continental crust should also be taken into account in the formation of 

the Rio Doce magmatic arc (see Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014, 2015 and 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 109

Araçuaí orogen. Note that the metamorphic grade of 

the country rocks roughly corresponds to the intrusive 

depth of the granitoids. Symbols as in Fig. 3.15. 

 

 

references therein for details). It is worth mentioning that fractional crystallization was argued as the 

first-order process responsible for the generation of the Divino Suite (Novo et al. 2010), and of the 

Brasilândia pluton (Tedeschi 2013), both formed by a group of rocks similar to the individualized 

Opx-bearing unit. Mixing and mingling, on the other hand, have been postulated as a likely process 

involved in the generation of the enclave-rich Galiléia Tonalite (Nalini Jr. et al. 2005). In addition, the 

inheritance of zircons of 2.1 Ga in the Rio Doce magmatic arc has been largely reported in the 

literature (Martins et al. 2004, Nalini Jr. et al. 2005, Petitgirard et al. 2009, Novo et al. 2010, Mondou 

et al. 2012, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014). The involvement of partial melting of 

the continental basement represented mainly by the Rhyacian gneisses in the formation of the Rio 

Doce magmatic arc is thus widely suggestive (e.g., Gonçalves et al. 2014 and references therein).  

Due to the overall field relationships, petrographic, geochemistry and isotopic characteristics, 

we proposed the geotectonic scenario illustrated by Figure 3.26 for the generation of the Rio Doce arc 

in the pre-collisional evolutionary stage of the Araçuaí orogen. Dehydration of the oceanic slab, partial 

melting of the metassomatized mantle wedge, coupled with significant melting of the older continental 

crust are presumably the main process acting in the Rio arc development.

CONCLUSIONS 

Our study of a magmatic section including G1 Supersuite plutonic and Rio Doce Group 

volcanosedimentary rocks exposed in the central portion of the Araçuaí orogen, lead to the following 

conclusions: 

1) The three distinct lithofacies units, the Opx-bearing rocks, enclave-rich Tonalite-

Granodiorite and enclave-poor Granite to Tonalite, dominate the magmatic succession in the studied 

area. The zone with Opx-bearing rocks occur along the western sector, forming a NS-elongated thrust 

slice sandwiched between Rhyacian orthogneisses of distinct metamorphic facies: to the west, the 

granulitic Juiz de Fora Complex, to the east, the amphibolite Pocrane Complex. On the other hand, the 

enclave-rich Tonalite-Granodiorite and enclave-poor Granite to Tonalite occur mainly in the central 

and eastern portions of the study area and preserve intrusive contacts with metasedimentary rocks of 

the Rio Doce Group. 

2) The magmatic lithofacies associations discriminated in the studied area consist mostly 

of granitoids chemically similar to a series of calc-alkaline, metaluminous to slightly peraluminous 

rocks, which are compositionally similar to Cordilleran-type arc sections.      

3) U-Pb zircon ages reveal that, in the study area, the rocks of the zone with Opx-bearing 

lithofacies crystallized between ca. 597 and 581 Ma, while the enclave-rich and enclave-poor rock 

associations crystallized respectively between 625 and 579 Ma, and between 593 and 576 Ma. 

Otherwise, the rhyolite belonging to the Rio Doce Group crystallized at ca. 578 Ma, suggesting thus 

that the studied plutonic and volcanic rocks might belong to the same magmatic event.   



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 111 

4) The zone with Opx-bearing rock unit represents the more primitive, in terms of SiO2 

content, and lowermost crust (~ 30 Km-depth), while the similarity in bulk composition, overlapping 

ages and close spatial relationship of the enclave-rich and enclave-poor rock associations suggest that 

they are petrogenetically related, and represent more evolved and shallower crustal levels (~20-25 

Km-depth) of the plutonic part of the arc. The volcanic counterpart - the arc roof - is represented by 

dacitic and rhyolitic volcanoclastic rocks of the Rio Doce Group.  

5) Field relationships combined with key mineralogical and chemical features suggest 

that the magmatic rock associations described in our study represent different crustal levels of a tilted 

crustal section in the central portion of the Araçuaí orogen.

CAPÍTULO 4 

A SUPERSUITE G1 ENTRE TEÓFILO OTONI E RIO DO PRADO: A 

TERMINAÇÃO INTRACONTINENTAL DO ARCO RIO DOCE 

“A person who never made a mistake, never tried anything new.” 

Albert Einstein 

4.1 – PANORAMA GEOLÓGICO REGIONAL 

A área de estudo compreendida entre as cidades de Teófilo Otoni e Rio do Prado, em Minas 

Gerais, está inserida na porção nordeste do núcleo cristalino do Orógeno Araçuaí (Alkmim et al. 2006, 

2007, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011) (Anexo I). O núcleo do Orógeno Araçuaí é constituído por rochas 

metamórficas de alto grau e um conjunto de supersuites graníticas Ediacaranas a Cambrianas, que 

marcam desde o estágio pre-colisional (Supersuite G1) até o colapso gravitacional (supersuites G4 e 

G5) do referido orógeno. Particularmente, na área estudada, as unidades aflorantes são as seguintes: 

- o Complexo Jequitinhonha;  

- o Grupo Rio Doce;  

- a Supersuite G1;  

- além das supersuites G2, G3 e G5.  

O Complexo Jequitinhonha constitui uma das unidades de maior abrangência do domínio 

interno do Orógeno Araçuaí e está localizado no extremo nordeste da área de trabalho (Anexo I). Este 

complexo representa a unidade mais antiga exposta na área e é formado por granada-biotita gnaisses, 

kinzigitos, quartzitos, gnaisses ricos em grafita, mármore e rochas meta-máficas (Almeida & Litwinski 

1984, Paes et al. 2010, Gonçalves-Dias et al. 2011, Gonçalves-Dias 2012). Uma característica 

marcante das rochas deste complexo é a ocorrência de feições migmatíticas, estas observadas 

principalmente nos paragnaisses (Fig. 4.1a).  

Determinações de idades U-Pb em zircões detríticos de quartzitos intercalados nos 

paragnaisses revelaram seis fontes principais (Fig. 4.1b) para os protólitos desta unidade (Gonçalves-

Dias et al. 2011, Gonçalves-Dias 2012). A população de zircões com idades médias de 2541 ± 8 Ma 

(6% dos valores) e 2044 ± 6 Ma (28%) sugerem que as rochas do embasamento do Paleocontinente 

São Francisco-Congo (e.g., Teixeira et al. 2000, Barbosa & Sabaté 2004, Noce et al. 2007) sejam as 

prováveis rochas fonte. Por outro lado, grãos de zircões detríticos com idades médias de 1819 ± 6 Ma 

(18%), 1487 ± 5 Ma (9%), e 1219 ± 3 Ma (24% dos valores) apontam para uma contribuição advinda 

de fontes magmáticas associadas ao sistema de riftes intracontinentais representado pelo Aulacógeno 

do Paramirim e Espinhaço Meridional  (e.g., Babinski et al. 1999, Danderfer et al. 2009, Chemale Jr.  



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 114 

Figura 4.1 – a) Paragnaisse migmatizado pertencente ao Complexo Jequitinhonha. Nota-se que o leucossoma 

encontra-se fortemente dobrado. b) Histograma de frequência, curva de probabilidade, em vermelho, e diagrama 
concórdia, canto superior direito, obtidos por meio de datação U-Pb (LA-ICP-MS) de zircões detríticos extraídos 

de quartzito intercalado em paragnaisse do Complexo Jequitinhonha (extraído de Gonçalves-Dias et al. 2011).  

 

et al. 2011), embora tais idades possam também refletir a erosão de rochas do cinturão Kibaride, 

relacionado ao Cráton do Congo (e.g., Kokonyangi et al. 2006). A população de zircões mais jovens 

com idade média de 956 ± 4 Ma (14% dos valores) sugerem que as fontes poderiam estar ligadas à 

erosão de rochas magmáticas expostas no sistema de riftes Noqui-Zadiniano-Mayumbiano, do cinturão 

Congo Ocidental (Tack et al. 2001), ou à erosão de rochas da Suite Salto da Divisa, localizada no 

Orógeno Araçuaí (Silva et al. 2008). A idade máxima de deposição para os protólitos do Complexo 

Jequitinhonha é de 898 ± 8 Ma (Gonçalves-Dias et al. 2011), sendo tal complexo interpretado como 

equivalente de alto grau da unidade tipo do Orógeno Araçuaí, o Grupo Macaúbas (Pedrosa-Soares et 

al. 2008, Gonçalves-Dias et al. 2011). 

O Grupo Rio Doce ocorre na porção sudoeste da área estudada (Anexo I) e é constituido por 

xistos pelíticos, quartzitos, orto- e para-gnaisses e meta-grauvacas. Este grupo contém ainda rochas 

dacíticas e riolíticas, expostas nas proximidades da cidade de Governador Valadares, cujas idades de 

cristalização estão em torno de 585 Ma (Vieira 2007, Gonçalves et al. 2010, 2014). A idade máxima 

de deposição das rochas deste grupo, estimada por meio de zircões detríticos extraídos de xistos e 

meta-grauvacas, é de 594 ± 3 Ma (Vieira 2007). Observações de campo, combinadas com estudos 

petrográficos, conduziram Vieira (2007), Pedrosa-Soares et al. (2011) e Gonçalves et al. (2010, 2014) 

a interpretar as rochas vulcânicas desta unidade como equivalentes às rochas G1 e o grupo, como um 

todo, como a sucessão de cobertura Neoproterozóica do arco magmático Rio Doce.  

A Supersuite G1 encontra-se amplamente distribuída pela área de estudo (Anexo I) e é 

formada por pequenos plutons (até ~ 5 Km
2
) e stocks (~ 80 Km

2
). Os principais plutons, localmente 

conhecidos como Rancho Alegre, Felizburgo, Pedra do Sino, Bom Jesus da Vitória, São Vítor e 

Topázio (Paes et al. 2010, Gonçalves et al. 2013), consistem de tonalitos (e seus equivalentes ricos em 

ortopiroxênio), granodioritos e em menor quantidade de monzogranitos. Trata-se de rochas 

essencialmente peraluminosas (com índice de saturação em alumínio, ASI, em média igual a 1,07), 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 115 

que envolvem fácies cálcicas (68 %), cálcio-alcalinas (24 %) e alcali-cálcicas (8 %), localmente 

portadoras de titanita e granada, mas comumente livres de hornblenda. As rochas G1, nesta região, são 

isotrópicas a foliadas, com ocorrência local de feições migmatíticas (Fig. 4.2a), e hospedeiras de 

enclaves meta-ígneos e meta-sedimentares, sendo os últimos mais frequentemente observados. Para 

maiores detalhes dos atributos dos granitóides pertencentes à terminação intracontinental do arco 

magmático Rio Doce vide a seção 4.3 a seguir. 

A Supersuite G2 ocorre na forma de plutons isolados e batólitos, principalmente nas porções 

central e sul da área de estudo (Anexo I), onde biotita-cordierita-granada-silimanita granitos foliados 

(Fig. 4.2b), são as rochas dominantes desta unidade (Paes et al. 2010, Gradim et al. 2014). Constituída 

essencialmente de granitos do tipo S, a Supersuite G2 possui idades de cristalização U-Pb obtidas em 

zircão entre 590 e 545 Ma (Nalini Jr. et al. 2000, Pedrosa-Soares & Wiedemann-Leonardos 2000, 

Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gradim et al. 2014). Neste intervalo teve lugar a principal fase de 

deformação e metamorfismo, até o momento, registrados no Orógeno Araçuaí (Silva et al. 2002, 2011, 

Alkmim et al. 2006, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Cavalcante et al. 2013, 2014, Gonçalves et al. 2014, 

Gradim et al. 2014, Uhlein et al. 2014, Peixoto et al. 2015). 

Comumente associada com rochas da Supersuite G2, a Supersuite G3 é constituida por corpos 

isotrópicos de granada-cordierita-silimanita leucogranitos (Fig 4.2c). Essencialmente formada por 

granitos do tipo S, as rochas G3 não foram individualizados na área estudada, devido à limitações na 

escala de mapeamento. A cristalização magmática dos plutons G3, tal como indicam idades U-Pb em 

zircão, fica situada entre 545 e 530 Ma, que corresponde ao intervalo de idades do magmatismo tardi-

colisional do Orógeno Araçuaí (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gradim et al. 2014). 

A Supersuite G5 encontra-se amplamente distribuída na área de estudo na forma de pequenos 

plutons ou batólitos (Anexo I), e consiste de monzogranitos, sienogranitos e charnoquitos não foliados 

(Fig. 4.2d). Localmente, estes granitóides mostram uma foliação restrita a zonas próximas ou mesmo 

no contato com as unidades mais antigas. Idades U-Pb em zircão obtidas neste trabalho, combinadas 

com dados da literatura, mostram que a cristalização dos granitos G5, que são essencialmente do tipo 

I, estão entre 530 e 480 Ma (e.g., De Campos et al. 2004, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011). As rochas G5, 

por seu turno, são interpretadas como o produto do magmatismo pós-colisional e tem sido 

relacionadas ao evento do colapso gravitacional do Orógeno Araçuaí (Alkmim et al. 2006, Pedrosa-

Soares et al. 2011).

4.2 – ARCABOUÇO ESTRUTURAL 

O acervo estrutural regional é composto por grandes zonas de cisalhamento de empurrão e 

reversas, zonas de cisalhamento oblíquas reversas dextrais e várias estruturas de pequena escala. Em  

função da orientação geral da foliação regional e da lineação de estiramento mineral a ela associada 

(Fig. 4.3, Anexo I), dois domínios estruturais, I e II, foram caracterizados na área de trabalho.  

No domínio estrutural I, tem-se que a foliação regional (Sn) possui mergulho predominante 

para NNE, com atitude preferencial 018/27, exibindo, porém, uma grande variação de atitude entre 

esta posição e 102/39 (Figs. 4.3 e 4.4). A lineação de estiramento (Ln) associada à foliação Sn varia 

igualmente entre os máximos de 066/23 e 083/20, com caimentos máximos de 030/41 e 117/72 (Fig. 

4.3). Nos diagramas estereográficos sinópticos de orientação da foliação Sn e da lineação Ln, observa-

se uma concentração da foliação Sn em 017/70, posição na qual a lineação Ln adquire a orientação

117/72. Esta disposição de estruturas ocorre, localmente, junto ao contato dos plutons G1 com as 

rochas encaixantes do Complexo Jequitinhonha. O sentido principal do transporte tectônico associado

norte de Mucuri (Fig. 4.3, Anexo I). Muito provavelmente, esta estrutura corresponde à continuidade e

ramo terminal norte da Zona de Cisalhamento de Abre Campo (ZCAC), que limita pelo oeste a

movimentação geral reversa dextral (vide mapa, Fig. 4.3 e Anexo I, bem como seções DD’ e EE’, Fig 

4.4 e Anexo I).  

Ao longo do domínio II, a foliação regional, por vezes milonítica, passa por variações de 

direção N-S a NE-SW, com mergulhos, entre 30 e 60º, tanto para E quanto para SE, adquirindo porém 

a orientação preferencial 112/45. A lineação de estiramento mineral (Ln) associada exibe, em 

consonância com as variações da foliação, caimentos ora para E, ora para SE (Fig. 4.3, Anexo I). A 

sua orientação preferencial é 083/19 (Fig. 4.3). De maneira similar ao que foi observado no domínio I, 

tem-se no domínio II, próximo ou mesmo no contato entre os plutons G1, G2 e G5 com as rochas 

encaixantes (Grupo Rio Doce e Complexo Jequitinhonha), uma variação na posição da foliação Sn e 

da lineação Ln, que adquirem as atitudes 100/80 e 087/83, respectivamente (Fig. 4.3). O sentido do 

transporte tectônico, no domínio II, varia entre SW e W, atestado por vários indicadores cinemáticos 

(Figs. 4.3, 4.4, Anexo I). 

 Ainda neste domínio, tem-se uma grande zona de cisalhamento de empurrão que possui 

orientação N-S entre os municípios de Pedro Versiani e pouco a norte de Topázio, adquirindo 

orientação geral NE-SW desde o norte de Topázio até as proximidades de Água Quente (Anexo I). A 

mudança de direção ao longo de tal zona de cisalhamento pode ser observada tanto em mapa (Fig. 4.3, 

Anexo I) quanto ao longo das seções regionais (CC’, DD’ e E’E’’) (Fig. 4.4). Porém, a intrusão dos 

plútons sin-colisionais G2 obliterou substancialmente esta zona. Em função disto, o seu traço em mapa 

é em grande parte inferido (Anexo I).    

Sob uma perspectiva mais ampla, o domínio I da área estudada, cujo sentido principal do 

transporte tectônico é dirigido para WSW, poderia representar a aba SW de uma grande estrutura em 

flor positiva (Gonçalves & Melo 2004) que se estenderia desta região até o limite com o Cráton São 

Francisco, nas proximidades do município de Camacan, na Bahia (Fig. 4.5), onde está situada a zona 

de cisalhamento transcorrente dextral de Itapebi (Fig. 4.5) (Alkmim et al. 2006). Ao considerar as 

estruturas da área estudada como o ramo sul da estrutura em flor associada à Zona de Cisalhamento de 

Itapebi, esta teria que exibir movimentação sinistral para a zona de cisalhamento Itapebi, que 

aparentemente não é o registro dominante. Porém, reativações tardias, normais sinistrais, ao longo da 

Zona de Cisalhamento de Itapebi, também já foram verificadas (Alkmim et al. 2006). Aliado a este 

fato, o grande número de intrusões tardias, essencialmente de plutons pertencentes à Supersuite G5, 

pode ter causado uma perturbação das estruturas preexitentes.

4.3 

GRANITES OF THE INTRACONTINENTAL TERMINATION OF A 

MAGMATIC ARC: AN EXAMPLE FROM THE EDIACARAN 

ARAÇUAÍ OROGEN, SOUTHEASTERN BRAZIL
 1
 

ABSTRACT 

The Araçuaí orogen of southeastern Brazil together with the West Congo belt of central West 

Africa form the Araçuaí-West Congo orogen generated during closure of a terminal segment of the 

Neoproterozoic Adamastor Ocean. Corresponding to an embayment in the São Francisco-Congo craton, 

this portion of the Adamastor was only partially floored by oceanic crust. The convergence of its margins 

led to the development of the Rio Doce magmatic arc between 630 Ma and 580 Ma. The Rio Doce 

magmatic arc terminates in the northern portion of the Araçuaí orogen. Granitic plutons exposed in the 

northern extremity of the arc provide a rare opportunity to study magmatism at arc terminations, and to 

understand the interplay between calc-alkaline magma production and crustal recycling. The plutons 

forming the terminus of the arc consist of granodiorites, tonalites and monzogranites similar to a 

magnesian, slightly peraluminous, calcic- (68%) to calc-alkaline (24%), with minor alkali-calcic (8%) 

facies, medium- to high-K magmatic series. Although marked by negative Nb-Ta, Sr and Ti anomalies, 

typically associated with subduction-related magmas, the combined Sr, Nd and Hf isotopic data 

characterize a crustal signature related to anatexis of metamorphosed igneous and sedimentary rocks, rather 

than fractional crystallization of mantle-derived magmas. Zircon U-Pb ages characterizes two groups of 

granitoids. The older group, crystallized between 630 and 590 Ma, experienced a migmatization event at 

ca. 585 Ma. The younger granitoids, emplaced between 570 and 590 Ma, do not show any evidence for 

migmatization. Most of the investigated samples show good correlation with the experimental 

compositional field of amphibolite dehydration-melting, with some samples plotting into the field of 

greywacke dehydration-melting. The studied rocks are not typical I-type or S-type granites, being 

particularly similar to transitional I/S-type granitoids described in the Ordovician Famatinian arc (NW 

Argentina). We suggest a hybrid model involving dehydration-melting of meta-igneous (amphibolites) and 

metasedimentary (greywackes) rocks for magma production in the northern termination of the Rio Doce 

arc. The real contribution of each end-member is, however, a challenging work still to be done.

INTRODUCTION 

Major and trace element data, together with Lu-Hf in zircon, whole-rock Sm-Nd and Rb-Sr 

isotopes provide sensitive discriminators of tectonic and/or magmatic processes operating above 

subduction zones and within collisional orogens (Rudnick 1995, Kemp & Hawkesworth 2003, Kemp 

et al. 2006, Liu et al. 2013, Niu et al. 2013). These chemistry and isotope datasets can also be used to 

discriminate between a range of geological processes involved in the pre-collisional to collisional 

stages of an orogenic belt evolution, such as crustal reworking, crust-mantle interactions, and 

production of juvenile magmas from the mantle.  

The Araçuaí orogen of southeastern Brazil and the West Congo belt of southwestern Africa 

once lie in the central portion of West Gondwana (Alkmim et al. 2001). Together, they form the 

Araçuaí-West Congo orogen (AWCO), generated during closure of a terminal branch of the 

Neoproterozoic Adamastor Ocean (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 1992, 2001, Brito Neves et al. 1999, Cordani 

et al. 2003, Alkmim et al. 2006). Emplacement of ophiolite slivers, development of intra-oceanic and 

continental-margin magmatic arcs, and collision of the plates represented by the São Francisco-Congo, 

Paranapanema, Rio de la Plata and Kalahari cratons record the Adamastor Ocean closure from the 

Cryogenian to Ediacaran periods (e.g., Pedrosa-Soares et al. 1998, 2011, Campos-Neto 2000, Alkmim 

et al. 2001, 2006, Basei et al. 2010, Tupinambá et al. 2012, Heilbron et al. 2013). Representing the 

northern segment of the Adamastoran orogenic system (e.g., Goscombe & Gray 2008), the AWCO 

exhibits a very peculiar configuration (Fig. 4.6), as it ended against a continental bridge linking the 

basement counterparts located in Bahia state (eastern Brazil) and Gabon (West Africa), the São 

Francisco-Congo cratonic bridge (Torquato & Cordani 1981, Porada 1989). In spite of this unique 

tectonic setting, the AWCO exhibits Late Cryogenian to Ediacaran ophiolite slivers and the Ediacaran 

Rio Doce magmatic arc, suggesting that its precursor was a gulf-like inland-sea embayment partially 

floored by oceanic crust (e.g., Pedrosa-Soares et al. 1998, 2011, Nalini Jr. et al. 2000, Alkmim et al. 

2006, Queiroga et al. 2007). 

The exhumed crystalline core of the Araçuaí orogen exposes a whole series of calc-alkaline 

plutons dated between 630 Ma and 580 Ma and grouped in the G1 Supersuite (Figs. 4.6 and 4.7), 

which represents the plutonic part of the Rio Doce magmatic arc (Figueiredo & Campos-Neto 1993, 

Nalini Jr. et al. 2000, Pedrosa-Soares & Wiedemann-Leonardos 2000, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, 

Gonçalves et al. 2014).  

Magmatic arcs developed along active margins rarely died out in intracontinental domains. 

Because of the peculiar tectonic setting of the AWCO, the G1 Supersuite plutons exposed in the 

northern Araçuaí orogen apparently mark the termination of the Rio Doce arc in a continental setting 

(Figs. 4.6 and 4.7). What is the chemical signature of granites formed in a magmatic arc dying out in 

an intracontinental domain? Are they chemically similar to granites formed in arcs developed on

active plate margins or more akin to collisional granites? What is the extent of crustal-mantle 

interaction and crustal recycling in such a highly ensialic setting? The G1 plutons of the northern 

Araçuaí orogen constitute a unique natural laboratory for providing answers to these questions and 

investigating features and process not yet well documented in the literature. In this paper, we present

Supersuite plutons exposed in the northern end of the Rio Doce arc. In order to discuss the nature of 

the granitic rocks generated in this particular setting, we compare our results with geochemical 

datasets from other segments of the Rio Doce arc and arc-related granites worldwide.

GEOLOGICAL SETTING 

The area we selected for study, encompassing a segment of ca. 10,000 km
2
 of the crystalline 

core of the Araçuaí orogen, is located between 16º30’ and 18º00’ S Lat., and 40º30’ and 42º00’ W 

Long., i.e., between the towns of Teófilo Otoni and Rio do Prado in northeastern Minas Gerais State, 

Brazil (Figs. 4.6 and 4.7). We chose this region because it is entirely covered by geologic maps 

(Fontes 2000, Moreira 2000, Paes 2000, Sampaio 2000, Gomes 2008, Paes et al. 2010) and contains 

good exposures of the northernmost plutons of the G1 Supersuite (Fig. 4.7).  

The evolution of the Araçuaí orogen between the Early Ediacaran up to the Cambrian-

Ordovician boundary produced an enormous volume of granitoids (including their Opx-bearing 

equivalents) and subordinate mafic rocks. Using field relationships, structural features, chemical and 

geochronological data, these igneous rocks were grouped into five assemblages, the G1, G2, G3, G4 

and G5 supersuites (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011). 

The granitic rocks forming the G1 Supersuite in the study area intrude with diffuse and sharp 

contacts the metasedimentary rocks of the Jequitinhonha Complex and the meta-volcanosedimentary 

Rio Doce Group, and are in turn cut by granites of the G2, G3 and G5 supersuites (Fig. 4.7).  

Representing the oldest rock assemblage in the study area, the Jequitinhonha Complex (Fig. 

4.7) consists of garnet-biotite gneisses, kinzigites, quartzites, graphite-rich gneisses, marbles, and 

metamafic rocks (Almeida & Litwinski 1984, Paes et al. 2010, Gonçalves-Dias et al. 2011). U-Pb 

determinations on detrital zircon grains from a quartzite intercalated with the paragneisses have 

yielded a maximum depositional age of 898 ± 8 Ma for protoliths of the complex (Gonçalves-Dias et 

al. 2011), which are interpreted as high grade equivalents of the Araçuaí orogen type unit, the Tonian-

Cryogenian Macaúbas Group (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2008, Gonçalves-Dias et al. 2011, and references 

therein). 

The Rio Doce Group crops out in the southwestern portion of the study area (Fig. 4.7), and 

comprises pelitic schists, quartzites, paragneisses, and metagreywackes. The group also contains 

dacitic and rhyolitic rocks dated around 585 Ma (Vieira 2007, Gonçalves et al. 2010, 2014). The 

maximum depositional age of the group, estimated at 594 ± 3 Ma, was constrained by the ages of 

detrital zircons extracted from schists and metagreywackes (Vieira 2007). Field observations and 

petrographic studies led Vieira (2007), Pedrosa-Soares et al. (2011), and Gonçalves et al. (2010, 2014) 

to interpret the volcanic rocks of this unit as equivalent to the G1 rocks and the group as a whole as a 

Rio Doce arc cover succession.  

In the study area, the G1 Supersuite includes small plutons (up to 5 km
2
) and stocks (up to 80 

km
2
). The main bodies, known as Rancho Alegre, Felizburgo, Pedra do Sino, Bom Jesus da Vitória, 

São Vítor and Topázio (Fig. 4.7), consist of tonalites (including Opx-bearing terms), granodiorites, 

and minor monzogranites. They are essentially peraluminous rocks (the ASI average is 1.07), 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 127 

involving calcic (68%), calc-alkaline (24%) and alkali-calcic (8%) facies, occasionally containing 

titanite or garnet, but commonly without hornblende. These rocks are isotropic to foliated, with local 

migmatitic features, and host both meta-igneous and metasedimentary enclaves, being the latter by far 

the more frequent (e.g., Paes et al., 2010 and references therein).  

In the remaining portions of the Araçuaí orogen, the G1 Supersuite consists of medium- to 

high-K, calc-alkaline, tonalitic to granitic bodies (including their Opx-bearing equivalents), and 

subordinate mafic to intermediate plutons containing gabbroic to enderbitic facies (Novo et al. 2010, 

Tedeschi 2013, Gonçalves et al. 2014). Typical for the majority of the G1 rocks is a large population 

of mafic enclaves (Nalini Jr. et al. 2000, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2010, 2014). All 

these characteristics, together with the pre-collisional nature of the G1 Supersuite, led most authors to 

interpret this rock assemblage as representative of a continental magmatic arc (e.g., Nalini Jr. et al. 

2000, 2005, Pedrosa-Soares & Wiedemann-Leonardos 2000, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2001, 2008, 2011, 

Martins et al. 2004, Novo et al. 2010, Tedeschi 2013, Gonçalves et al. 2010, 2014), named Rio Doce 

arc by Figueiredo & Campos-Neto (1993). The development of the Rio Doce arc, constrained by 

zircon U-Pb ages between 630 and 580 Ma, is viewed as a consequence of the consumption of the 

oceanic segment of the Adamastor terminal branch, which took place before the collisional event that 

led to the full development of the AWCO (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 1998, 2001, 2008, Alkmim et al. 

2006, Gonçalves et al. 2014).    

The G2 Supersuite occurs in the form of isolated plutons or batholiths mainly in the central 

and southern portions of the study area (Fig. 4.7), where foliated biotite-cordierite-garnet-sillimanite 

granites predominate (Gradim et al. 2014). Made up essentially of S-type granites, the G2 Supersuite 

show U-Pb ages between 590 Ma and 545 Ma (e.g., Nalini Jr. et al. 2000, Pedrosa-Soares & 

Wiedemann-Leonardos 2000, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gradim et al. 2014). This interval 

corresponds to the main phase of deformation and metamorphism recorded in the Araçuaí orogen 

(Silva et al. 2002, 2011, Alkmim et al. 2006, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gonçalves et al. 2014, 

Gradim et al. 2014).  

Commonly associated with the G2 rocks, the G3 Supersuite is made up of isotropic garnet-

cordierite-sillimanite leucogranites. Mostly composed of S-type granites, the G3 rocks are not 

individualized in the study area, due to limitations on the scale of mapping. Its magmatic 

crystallization is constrained by zircon ages between 545 Ma and 530 Ma, representing the late-

collisional stage of the Araçuaí orogen (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011, Gradim et al. 2014). 

The G4 Supersuite occurs as zoned plutons or batholiths in the region to the south of the study 

area (Fig. 4.6) and consists of non-foliated biotite granite, two-mica and muscovite-garnet 

leucogranites. Commonly, G4 plutons show igneous flow structures and are peraluminous.  Zircon U-

Pb data constrain the magmatic crystallization age of the S-type G4 granitoids between 530 Ma and 



Gonçalves L. E. da S. Contribuição à geoquímica, geocronologia, estrutura e evolução dos segmentos central .... 

 128 

500 Ma (e.g., Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011 and references therein). According to Alkmim et al. (2006) 

and Pedrosa-Soares et al. (2011), together with the G5 Supersuite, the G4 granites represent the 

product of  a magmatic event related to the orogenic collapse phase of the Araçuaí orogen.     

The G5 Supersuite occurs as small or large plutons widespread in the study area (Fig. 4.7), and 

consists of non-foliated monzogranite, syenogranite, and charnockites. Locally, these granitoids are 

foliated close to their contact with the older units. U-Pb data on zircon grains from the study area 

combined with ages from different parts of the orogen constrain the crystallization ages of the I-type 

G5 granitoids between 530 Ma and 480 Ma (e.g., De Campos et al. 2004, Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2011). 

 

ANALYTICAL METHODS                     

Representative samples of the G1 Supersuite granitoids were chosen for lithochemical (8 

samples), geochronological (U-Pb – 10 samples, Lu-Hf – 4 samples) and isotopic (Sm-Nd, Rb-Sr – 6 

samples) analyses. Additionally, two samples of the G2 rocks and one sample of the G5 Supersuite 

were dated (U-Pb zircon analyses). Care was taken to select fresh and homogenous parts of the 

samples, avoiding weathered, metamorphosed, or late veins. All the samples were crushed and milled 

at the Departamento de Geologia of the Universidade Federal de Ouro Preto, Brazil. Major, trace and 

rare earth element (REE) concentrations were determined at the ACME Analytical Laboratory LTDA, 

Vancouver, Canada. Major oxides were analyzed via Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission 

(ICP-AES) after fusion with lithium metaborate-tetraborate and digestion with diluted nitric acid. 

Trace and REE concentrations were analyzed via Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry 

(ICP-MS) adopting the same procedure previously mentioned as for major oxides. Detection limits are 

0.01% for oxides and 0.1-0.01 ppm for trace, and Rare Earth elements. The Loss On Ignition (LOI) 

was determined by the weighting difference after ignition at 1000 ºC. The geochemical dataset of 

samples from the literature as well as data from this study are presented as Supplementary Data - Item 

1.  

U–Pb zircon Laser Ablasion Multicollector Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry 

(LA-MC-ICP-MS, Neptune Thermo Scientific) analyses were carried out at the Geochronology 

Laboratory of the Universidade de São Paulo, Brazil. Samples were prepared for analysis in 

laboratories of Universidade Federal de Ouro Preto and Universidade de São Paulo, Brazil. Zircon 

grains were separated using conventional methods (crushing, grinding, gravimetric and magnetic-

Frantz isodynamic separator), and handpicked under binocular microscope. Only zircon crystals from 

the least magnetic fractions were selected for geochronological analysis. Selected zircon grains were 

mounted in an epoxy disk and polished to expose the interiors. The morphology and internal structure 

of zircons were characterized by optical microscopy and cathodoluminescence (CL) imaging. The 

mount disks were then cleaned and the U-Pb isotopic compositions of zircon were analyzed. A spot 



Contribuições às Ciências da Terra – Série D, vol. 33, 180p. 

 129 

size of 25 ?m was applied to all analyses. Zircon GJ-1 (Jackson et al. 2004) was used as an external 

standard and was analyzed twice every 6 analyses. Analytical spots were conducted avoiding grain 

areas with inclusions, fractures and metamictic structures. Data reduction used the Excel sheet 

developed by Chemale Jr. et al. (2012). For all samples the data of each spot was evaluated taking into 

account the common Pb contents, errors of isotopic ratios, percentages of discordance and Th/U ratios. 

Selected spots used for age calculations were those with discordance lower than 10%. Concordia 

diagrams were obtained with the software Isoplot/Ex (Ludwig 2003). U-Pb analytical data and 

concordia diagrams are shown as Supplementary Data - Item 2 and in figure 4.15. 

The Sm-Nd (ID-TIMS) and Sr (“natural”) isotope analyses were performed in the 

Geochronology and Radiogenic Isotope Laboratory (LAGIR) at UERJ, the Rio de Janeiro State 

University. The analyzed samples were 4 granodiorites, 1 tonalite and 1 enderbite belonging to the G1 

Supersuite, and the results are shown as Supplementary Data – Item 3 and in figure 4.16. Clean rooms 

were used with positive air pressure and double-HEPA air filtering. Each rock powder sample 

weighting up to 50 mg was mixed with an isotope tracer solution of

RESULTS 

Petrography 

 The selected samples for detailed petrographic studies were collected in the G1 bodies known 

as Rancho Alegre, Felizburgo, Pedra do Sino, Bom Jesus da Vitória, São Vítor and Topázio plutons 

(Fig. 4.7). The first four plutons, exposed in the central-northeastern sector of the study area, intrude 

rocks of the Jequitinhonha Complex, whereas the last two cut Rio Doce Group rocks in the 

southwestern portion of the study area (Fig. 4.7). These plutons are composed mainly of tonalites, 

granodiorites and minor monzogranites (Table 4.1). The dominant lithotypes are light to medium gray, 

fine to coarse-grained, and consist mostly of plagioclase (33–52%), quartz (23–48%), K-feldspars 

(10–38%; microcline and orthoclase), biotite (2–25%), and minor hornblende (~3%), the latter mineral 

being restricted to the Bom Jesus da Vitória pluton. Zircon, apatite, titanite, garnet, epidote, hematite, 

magnetite and ilmenite are common accessory minerals, whilst rutile, muscovite, allanite, monazite, 

pyrrhotite, pyrite and chalcopyrite are restricted to few samples. Muscovite and carbonates are 

secondary products of plagioclase breakdown. Chlorite occurs as replacement of biotite.

Table 4.1 - Summary of the key main features of the Jequitinhonha paragneisses and G1 granitic rocks exposed 

in the study area. 

 

The studied granitoids are, in general, strongly foliated, showing locally migmatitic features 

(Figs. 4.8a-b). Undeformed phases also occur, especially in the central portion of the plutons. 

Preserved igneous features such as zoned and tabular plagioclase crystals were observed in Topázio, 

São Vítor and Pedra do Sino plutons (Fig. 4.8c). Solid-state deformation features, such as elongated 

grains, undulose extinctions, mechanical twinning, deformation bands, and occasionally quartz 

subgrains dominate the texture of the rocks (Figs. 4.8d-e). The associated metamorphic foliation is 

marked by the alignment of biotite and hornblende. Brown-reddish biotite is mostly euhedral to 

subhedral and shows pleochroic halos given by metamictic zircon and monazite grains. Hornblende 

grains occur as anhedral to subhedral crystals. 

 

Geochemistry 

 Eight samples of G1 Supersuite rocks were analyzed for major and trace elements 

(Supplementary Data – Item 1). Additional major and trace element compositions of 17 samples from 

the study area analyzed by Paes et al. (2010) are also shown in the diagrams of figure 4.9. For 

comparison, we also plotted approximately 200 chemical analyses of granitic rocks belonging to the 

central-southern portions of the Rio Doce arc (shaded areas in the diagrams of figure 4.9) (see 

Gonçalves et al. 2014 for data source), 50 chemical compositions of samples from Grosse et al. 

(2011), mainly for major element comparisons, and 12 from Pankhurst et al. (1998), mainly for trace 

element comparisons, belonging to the Famatinian magmatic arc, which show similar lithochemical 

attributes when compared with the Rio Doce magmatic arc (Fig. 4.10).  

The analyses of this study and those of Paes et al. (2010) show a range of compositions from 

tonalite to monzogranite. Granodiorite (52%) and tonalite (32%) represent by far the most common 

rocks (Fig. 4.9a). They have a SiO2 content ranging from 61.66% to 78.27% (see Supplementary Data

The samples show a clear negative correlation between TiO2, Al2O3, Fe2O3 and MgO with 

SiO2, and although more scattered, CaO (1.84 - 5.81 wt.%) data also show a slightly negative 

correlation with SiO2 (Figs. 4.10a-e), suggesting fractionation of mafic minerals. On the other hand, a 

slightly positive correlation between SiO2 and Na2O is observed (Fig. 4.10f). No clear correlation is 

observed between SiO2 and K2O, although K2O generally increases with SiO2 (Fig. 4.10g). The 

Alumina Saturation Index does not show correlation with SiO2 (Fig. 4.10h).

The analyzed samples display REE patterns characterized by enrichment in Light Rare Earth 

Elements (LREE) over Heavy Rare Earth Elements (HREE), with (La/Yb)N ratios ranging between 

~11 and ~63 (Supplementary Data - Item 1, Fig. 4.11). All samples record a negative Eu anomaly, 

with Eu/Eu* ratios ranging from ~0.33 to ~0.79 (Supplementary Data - Item 1). In Primitive Mantle-

normalized incompatible element spidergrams (Figs. 4.12a-d), the G1 rocks show overall Large Ion 

Lithophile Elements (LILE)-enriched patterns (Rb, Th), with values between 100-600 times higher 

than the Primitive Mantle values (Sun & McDonough 1989). This pattern combined with positive Th, 

La, Ce, P and Zr anomalies suggests important crustal sourcing. Other common chemical 

characteristic of the analyzed rocks is the negative Nb, Ta, Sr and Ti anomalies (Fig. 4.12b), which is 

normally referred to as an “arc-like signature” (see Niu et al. 2013, and references therein for details). 

 

Geochronology 

Age determinations were performed on 10 rock samples (Figs. 4.7, 4.13-4.15): 7 samples from 

the G1 Supersuite; 2 samples from the G2 Supersuite; and 1 sample from the G5 Supersuite. The 

analyzed samples correspond to one enderbite, one tonalite, seven granodiorites, and one syenogranite. 

A summary of the main features of the dated samples are shown on Tables 4.2 and 4.3 and figures 

4.13 to 4.15. 

 

G1 Supersuite (samples LG21, LG27, LG28, LG31, LG49, LG63, and LG173) 

The studied G1 Supersuite plutons showed that six samples (LG21, LG27, LG28, LG49, 

LG63 and LG173) have zircon grains with inherited cores on CL images (Fig. 4.14). Attempts to date 

these cores failed and no coherent age data could be obtained, however apparent ages (from 958 Ma to 

2574 Ma) are suggestive of inheritance from rocks of the Jequitinhonha Complex (e.g., Gonçalves-

Dias et al., 2011). Three samples (LG21, LG31 and LG173) gave ages of 574 ± 7 Ma, 575 ± 6 Ma, and 

584 ± 13 Ma, respectively, which are interpreted as their crystallization ages (Figs. 4.15a, d, g and 

Tables 4.2 and 4.3). On the other hand, four samples (LG27, LG28, LG49 and LG63) have zircon 

grains, which were divided in two populations, giving ages of ca. 618-595 Ma for crystallization (Fig. 

4.15b-I, c-I, e-I, f-I and Tables 4.2 and 4.3) and ca. 555-589 Ma for overgrowths or new crystallized 

zircon grains (Fig. 4.15b-II, c-II, e-II, f-II and Tables 4.2 and 4.3) interpreted as a migmatization event 

affecting the rocks. Assuming that this interpretation is correct, the obtained results more likely reflect 

the regional metamorphic event that took place in the Araçuaí orogen beween 590 Ma to 545 Ma, 

peaking at 575 Ma (Pedrosa-Soares et al. 2001, 2011, Silva et al. 2011, Gradim et al. 2014, Peixoto et 

al. 2015).

Table 4.3 - Summary of the main characteristics of zircon grains from the studied G1 granitic rocks. 

 

G2 Supersuite (samples LG12 and LG161)  

The zircon grains extracted from sample LG12 (Caraí pluton) comprise mainly short-

prismatic, and minor elongated grains (up to 422 ?m) with length/width ratios in average of 4:1, 

although higher ratios up to 6:1 can be observed. The axes of zircon grains range from 37 ?m to 422 

?m. Most grains are dark-gray and some display magmatic oscillatory zoning with inherited cores on 

CL images (Fig. 4.14). Several attempts to date these cores were unsuccessful due to the high level of 

discordance, although apparent ages ranging mainly from ca. 800 Ma to 1200 Ma could be observed. 

Most zircon grains have Th/U ratios ranging from 0.10 to 0.83 (Supplementary Data – Item 2). 

Thirteen concordant to near-concordant (<4% disc.) spot analyses from 12 zircon grains yielded a 

concordia age of 538 ± 8 Ma (MSWD = 0.21) (Fig. 4.15h). This age is interpreted as the best 

approximation of the crystallization age of this sample.  

 Sample LG161 (Wolff pluton) contains short- and long-prismatic zircon grains, with 

length/width ratios in average of 4:1, although higher ratios up to 6:1 are observed. The axes of zircon 

grains range from 47 ?m to 330 ?m. They are light-gray and some grains display magmatic oscillatory 

zoning with inherited cores on CL images (Fig. 4.14). Attempts to obtain ages from these cores failed 

due to the high level of discordance, although apparent ages mainly between ~960 Ma and ~2000 Ma 

are found. Four zircon grains have Th/U ratios between 0.38 and 1.22, whilst two other grains have 

Th/U ratios of 0.02 and 0.03 (Supplementary Data – Item 2).  Six concordant to near-concordant spot 

analyses obtained in the same number of zircon grains yielded a concordia age of 563 ± 9 Ma (MSWD 

= 0.54) (Fig. 4.15i). We interpret this age as the magmatic crystallization age of this sample.

G5 Supersuite (sample LG29)         

 The zircon grains extracted from sample LG29 (Fazenda Liberdade pluton) consist of 

predominantly short-prismatic grains, with length/width ratios in average of 2.6:1, although 

higher ratios up to 5:1 are observed. The axes of zircon grains range from 45 ?m to 245 ?m. 

Most grains are light-gray, and seldom display magmatic oscillatory zoning with no inherited 

cores on CL images (Fig. 4.14). Many zircon grains have Th/U ratios higher than 1 

(Supplementary Data – Item 2). Thirty one concordant (<2% disc.; except one grain with 4% 

disc.) spot analyses obtained in the same number of zircon grains yielded a concordia age of 

526 ± 5 Ma (MSWD = 0.12) (Fig. 4.15j). This age is interpreted as the best approximation of 

the crystallization age of this sample.
